2-4061   Procedure.
ARTICLE A
Purchasing
Section 2-4001 Disbursement of funds.
   (a)   In accordance with the Local Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act,
no bill or claim against the Town may be paid unless it has been approved by
the officer or employee responsible for the function or agency to which the
expense is charged. No check or draft of the Town shall be valid unless it
bears on its face the certificate of the Finance Officer as follows:
   "This disbursement has been approved as required by the Local Government
Budget and Fiscal Control Act."
   (b)   No contract, agreement or purchase order shall be valid unless it
bears the finance officer's certificate as follows:
   “This instrument has been preaudited in the manner required by the Local
Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act.”
   State Law Reference: Preaudit of disbursements required, G.S. 159-28, as
amended.
   Cross Reference: Town Manager to serve as purchasing agent, Charter, Section
2-6.
Section 2-4002 through 2-4010 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Privilege License Taxes
Section 2-4011 Definitions.
   Wherever in this article the following words are used, such words shall,
unless the context requires otherwise, be deemed to have the following
meanings:
   (1)   Person. Includes any individual, trustee, executor, other fiduciary,
corporation, unincorporated association, partnership, sole proprietorship,
company, firm, or other legal entity.
   (2)   Business. Includes each trade, occupation, profession, business, and
franchise taxed under this article.
   (3)   Seasonal business. A business that is conducted for profit six months
out of the year or less.
   (4)   Wholesale. The sale of goods, usually in quantities, by a supplier to
a business which will in turn retail the goods.
   (5)   Retail. The direct sale of goods or services, usually in small
quantities, to an individual consumer.
   (6)   Schedule B. Refers to Schedule B of the North Carolina Revenue Act
(G.S. 105-33 to G.S. 105-113).
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
   State Law Reference: Privilege license taxes, G.S. 160A-211. See also
Schedule “B” of the Revenue Act or 1939, as amended (G.S. 105, Article 2) which
specifies whether a city or town may levy a license tax of businesses taxed
under this Schedule.
Section 2-4012 Construction of this article.
   This article is enacted for revenue purposes only. Therefore, it should be
construed to require payment of the maximum tax permitted under its terms. In
addition, issuance of a license in accordance with this article does not excuse
a licensee from compliance with any other applicable ordinance or statute. This
article does not prevent the town from imposing license taxes on additional
businesses, from increasing or decreasing the amount of any license tax, or
from regulating any business taxed.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4013 Levy of tax.
   An annual privilege license tax is hereby levied on each business conducted
within the Town of Canton listed in Section
2-4044, in the amounts set forth.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4014 Who must pay tax.
   Each person who conducts a business within the Town is subject to this
article. A person "conducts business" when he or she engages in one act of
business taxed under this article. He or she conducts the business "within the
Town" if he or she maintains a business location within the Town; or if, either
personally or through agents, he or she:
   (1)   Solicits business within the Town limits; or
   (2)   Picks up or delivers goods or services within the Town limits.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4015 Period of license; due date.
   (a)   Annual licenses. Unless the section of this article levying the
privilege license tax applicable to a particular business provides otherwise, a
license issued in accordance with this article is good for the 12-month period
beginning July 1 and ending June 30. The tax is due on July 1 of each year.
However, if a person begins a business after July 1 of a year, the tax for that
year is due before the business is begun.
   (b)   Licenses for periods shorter than one year. If the section of this
article levying the privilege license tax applicable to a particular business
so provides, a license may be issued for a period of one day, one week, or some
comparable period of less than a full license year. A person may not commence a
business conducted within the Town and taxed under such a provision until the
privilege license tax due is paid, and may not continue such a business beyond
the period for which the license is issued.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
   Cross Reference: Charter provisions on license tax, Charter, Section
3-1.
Section 2-4016 Proration of tax.
   If a business is begun after January 31 and before July 1, the amount of tax
due is half the amount otherwise due. If a business is seasonal in nature and
if the amount of tax is not based on gross receipts, the amount of tax due is
half the amount otherwise due.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4017 Refunds.
   If for any reason a licensee discontinues his or her business during the
license year, he or she is not entitled to a refund.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4018 Separate businesses.
   A separate license is required and a separate privilege license tax must be
paid for each place of business unless two or more places of business under
common ownership are contiguous to each other, communicate directly with and
open into each other, and are operated as a unit. In addition a separate
privilege license tax must be paid for each business taxable under this article
conducted by the taxpayer at any one location; however, the Tax Collector may
issue a single license for all taxable business conducted at one location by a
single taxpayer.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4019 Computation of tax based on gross receipts.
   (a)   Whenever this article levies a privilege license tax computed on the
basis of gross receipts, "gross receipts" means the amount reported as gross
receipts on a business's state income tax return, or on the federal income tax
return filed with the state income tax return if the state return does not
separately state gross receipts for the most recently completed tax year.
   (b)   If a business has not been in operation long enough for the
information required in subsection (a) above to be available, the Tax Collector
shall estimate gross receipts for the business on the basis of gross receipts
of comparable businesses, or any other information that the Tax Collector
considers useful.
   (c)   On or before the July 31 immediately after the license year, each
licensee who paid the tax for the past license year based on estimated gross
receipts shall submit to the Tax Collector a sworn final report showing the
amount of gross receipts for the license year. If the amount shown is more than
estimated gross receipts, the licensee shall pay the amount of additional tax
that would have been due had the estimate been accurate. If the amount shown is
less than estimated gross receipts, the Town shall refund to the licensee the
difference between the actual tax paid and the amount of tax that would have
been due had the estimate been accurate.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4020 Exemptions.
   (a)   Generally. Except as otherwise provided in this section or by state
law, no person is exempt from the payment of the privilege license tax levied
by this article.
   (b)   Charitable organizations. A person who operates a business for a
religious, educational, civic, patriotic, charitable, or fraternal purpose,
when the entire gross income of the business is used for such a purpose, is
exempt from paying any privilege license tax levied by this article.
   (c)   Blind persons and members of the armed forces and merchant marine.
Blind persons and persons who serve in the United States armed forces or the
merchant marine are exempt from paying any privilege license tax levied by this
article to the extent provided by G.S. 105-249 and G.S. 105-249(I).
   (d)   Must obtain license. A person exempt from paying a privilege license
tax levied by this article shall nevertheless obtain a license from the Tax
Collector. The license shall state that the licensee is exempt from paying the
privilege license tax.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4021 Application for license.
   A person shall apply to the Tax Collector for each license required by this
article no less than 30 days before the date the tax is due. The application,
which shall be submitted on forms provided by the Tax Collector, shall contain:
   (1)   The name of the applicant and whether the applicant is an individual,
a partnership, a corporation, or some other entity;
   (2)   The nature of the business;
   (3)   Where the business conducted;
   (4)   An address where notices and statements may be mailed to as required
by this article;
   (5)   Whether the business is regulated by a state occupational licensing
board subject to G.S. Chapter 938, and if so, the serial number of the state
license the applicant currently holds; and
   (6)   Any other information the Tax Collector determines to be necessary to
compute the amount of tax due.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4022 Reasons for refusal or revocation of a license.
   The Tax Collector shall refuse to issue a license or shall revoke a license
for either of the following reasons:
   (1)   The applicant misrepresents a fact relevant to the amount of tax due
or his or her qualifications for a license;
   (2)   The applicant refuses to provide information necessary to compute the
amount of tax due;
   (3)   The applicant has not paid the privilege license tax or ad valorem tax
due for prior year(s); and/or
   (4)   The applicant has not yet obtained a State or County license, in
instances where State law requires payment of these licenses prior to issuance
of town licenses.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4023 Unqualified applicants; right to a conference.
   (a)   After receipt of the completed application, if the Tax Collector
believes that a reason exists for refusing a license under Section
2-4022, the Tax Collector shall refuse to accept payment of the tax and shall
not issue the license. At the applicant's request, the Tax Collector shall, in
accordance with Section
2-4022, give the applicant a written statement of the reason for refusing the
license. The applicant may, within ten days after the day the statement is
received, request a conference to discuss the refusal. In the request the
applicant shall specify why the application for a license should not be
refused. The Tax Collector shall arrange the conference within a reasonable
time.
   (b)   If the Collector refuses to issue a license, the applicant may reapply
for a license at any time thereafter. If the reason for which the application
was refused no longer exists, and if no other reason exists for refusing to
issue a license, the Tax Collector shall issue the license in compliance with
Section
2-4024.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4024 Tax Collector to issue license; meant of tax a prerequisite.
   After receipt of the completed application, if the Tax Collector believes
that no reason exists for refusal of a license under Section
2-4022, he or she shall determine the amount of tax due and notify the
applicant of that amount. The Tax Collector shall not issue a license until the
tax is paid.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4025 Amount of tax disputed.
   If disputes arise over the amount the Tax Collector determines to be due,
the applicant may either refuse to pay and request a conference with the Tax
Collector to discuss the determination or pay the amount and request a
conference to discuss the right to a refund. If a conference is requested, the
Tax Collector shall arrange it within a reasonable time.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4026 Revocation of license.
   (a)   The Tax Collector shall revoke a license if a reason exists to revoke
it as set forth in Section
2-4022. Before revoking a license, the Tax Collector shall give the licensee
written notice of the grounds for revocation, in accordance with Section
2-4032. The licensee may, within ten days after the day on which notice is
served, request a conference with the Tax Collector in writing. The request
shall specify the reasons why the license should not be revoked. The Tax
Collector shall arrange the conference within a reasonable time.
   (b)   If the licensee fails to request a conference within ten days after
the day on which notice is served, the Tax Collector shall revoke the license.
If the licensee requests a conference, the Tax Collector may not revoke the
license until after the conference.
   (c)   If the Tax Collector revokes a license, the former licensee may apply
for a new license at any time thereafter. If the reason for which the license
was revoked no longer exists and if no other reason exists for refusing to
issue a license, the Tax Collector shall issue the license in accordance with
Section
2-4024.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4027 Form and contents of license.
   A license shall show the name of the person licensed, the place where the
business is conducted (if it is to be conducted at one place), the nature of
the business licensed, the period for which the license is issued, and the
amount of tax paid. In addition, if a machine is licensed, the license shall
show the serial number of the machine. The Tax Collector shall keep a copy of
each license issued.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4028 Assignments.
   A license may be assigned if:
   (1)   A business licensed under this article and carried on at a fixed place
is sold as a unit to any person; and
   (2)   The purchaser is to carry on the same business at the same place. Such
a change shall be reported to the Tax Collector in accordance with Section
2-4029. Otherwise, each license issued under this article is a personal
privilege and is not assignable.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4029 Changes in the business conducted by the licensee during the tax
year.
   A licensee or an assignee shall report a change in the information contained
in the license application to the Tax Collector within ten days after the
change occurs. If information shown on the license itself is affected, the
licensee or assignee shall surrender the license to the Tax Collector when
reporting the change.
   (1)   Changes affecting the amount of tax due. If there are no reasons for
revoking the license under Section
2-4022 and the change results in the imposition of a separate or additional
tax, the Tax Collector shall reissue a license reflecting the change upon
payment of the separate or additional tax.
   (2)   Changes not affecting the amount of tax due. If there are no reasons
for revoking the license under Section
2-4022 and the change does not result in an imposition of a separate or
additional tax, the Tax Collector shall reissue a license reflecting the change
upon payment of a fee of $5.
   (3)   Change requiring refusal of a license. If there is reason for revoking
the license under Section
2-4022, the Tax Collector shall refuse to reissue a license and shall instead
begin proceedings to revoke the license in accordance with Section
2-4016.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4030 Tax Collector to furnish duplicates.
   Upon satisfactory proof that a license has been lost or destroyed, the Tax
Collector shall furnish a duplicate for a fee of $5.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4031 Record of conferences.
   The Tax Collector shall maintain for three years a record of each conference
held in accordance with this article. The record shall contain the applicant or
licensee's name, the date of the conference, and a brief statement of the
issues discussed and the result reached. After three years, the Tax Collector
shall dispose of the record in accordance with G.S. 121-5.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4032 Providing notice to an applicant or licensee.
   Whenever this article requires the Tax Collector to give a written statement
or notice to an applicant or a licensee, the Tax Collector may do so in one of
three ways:
   (1)   By personally delivering the statement or notice to the applicant or
licensee;
   (2)   By mailing the statement or notice by registered or certified mail and
returning the receipt requested to the address specified for that purpose in
the license application; or
   (3)   By causing the statement or notice to be served on the applicant or
licensee in accordance with the procedures for service of process under Rule 4,
North Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4033 Duty to determine whether tax due.
   Each person has the duty to determine whether the business he or she
conducts is taxed under this article and if so, whether that tax has been paid
for the current tax year.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4034 Tax Collector to investigate.
   If the Tax Collector has reason to believe that a person is conducting a
business in the Town in violation of this article, the Tax Collector shall
conduct an investigation to determine the person’s tax liability.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4035 Duty to keep books.
   Each person who conducts a business taxed under this article shall keep all
records and books necessary to compute the tax liability. If a person fails to
keep books and records as required, the Tax Collector shall make a
determination of that person’s tax liability from the information available.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4036 Duty to permit inspection.
   Each person who conducts business in the Town shall permit the Tax Collector
to inspect the business premises during normal business hours to determine the
nature of the business conducted there and to examine the books and records to
determine the nature and amount of business transacted.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4037 Duty to post license.
   A licensee shall post the license or licenses conspicuously in the place of
business licensed. If the licensee has no regular place of business, the
license must be kept where it may be inspected at all times by the proper Town
officials. If a machine is licensed, the license shall be affixed to the
machine.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4038 Notice of deficiency.
   If the Tax Collector determines that a person has not paid the full amount
of tax due under this article, either for the current license year or for a
prior license year, the Tax Collector shall give the person written notice of
the deficiency, in accordance with Section
2-4032. The notice of deficiency shall specify the total amount of tax due; the
section of this article upon which the tax is based; the amount of tax paid;
any interest due; the balance owed; the manner and time period in which the
person may respond to the notice of the deficiency, and the consequences of
failing to respond as specified.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4039 Request for a conference.
   The person may, within ten days after the day on which notice is served,
request a conference in writing. The request shall specify the person's
objections to the notice of deficiency. By way of illustration but not
limitation, a person who receives notice of a deficiency may object on the
following grounds:
   (1)   The tax due has already been paid;
   (2)   The Tax Collector miscalculated the amount of tax due;
   (3)   The Tax Collector based his or her calculation on incorrect or
insufficient information concerning either the nature or the amount of business
conducted; or
   (4)   The Tax Collector based the determination on an erroneous
interpretation of a section of this article that establishes a category of
business subject to a particular tax.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4040 Deficiency to become final.
   If the taxpayer fails to request a conference under Section
2-4039, the deficiency becomes final and the Tax Collector shall proceed to
collect the deficiency.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4041 Conference held.
   If the taxpayer requests a conference, the Tax Collector shall not proceed
to collect the deficiency until hearing the taxpayer's objection's and
determining that the deficiency should become final. The Tax Collector shall
maintain a record of each conference held for three years in accordance with
Section
2-4039. The record shall contain the name of the taxpayer, the date of the
conference, a brief statement of the issues discussed, and the results of the
discussion. After three years, the Tax Collector shall dispose of the record in
compliance with G.S. 121-5.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4042 Collection of deficiency.
   (a)   The Tax Collector may use any of the following methods to collect a
deficiency:
   (1)   Criminal prosecution in accordance with Section
2-4043(a);
   (2)   Equitable relief in accordance with Section
2-4043(b); or
   (3)   The remedies of levy, sale, attachment and garnishment in accordance
with G.S. 160A-207.
   (b)   Any person who continues to conduct a business taxed under this
article without payment of the tax is liable for the additional tax of 5% every
30 days as imposed by G.S. 105-109.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4043 Enforcement of this article.
   (a)   Criminal remedies. Conducting business within the Town without having
paid the privilege license tax imposed by this article, or without a valid
license issued in accordance with this article, or without posting a license in
compliance with Section 2- 4037 is a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in
G.S. 105-109 or G.S. 14-4. Each day that a person conducts business in
violation of this article is a separate offense. Payment of a fine imposed in
criminal proceedings in accordance with this section does not relieve a person
of the liability for taxes imposed under this article.
   (b)   Equitable remedies. In addition to the criminal remedies set forth in
subsection (a) above and in compliance with G.S. 160A-175(d), the Town may seek
an injunction against any person who conducts a business in violation of this
article.
(Ord. of 6/25/02)
Section 2-4044 Taxable business categories and fees.
   (a)   All businesses listed in Schedule B of the North Carolina Revenue Act,
and any amendments thereto, as may from time to time be enacted, are hereby
adopted by reference with the respect to the issuance of a privilege license by
the Town.
   (b)   All businesses listed in Schedule B of the North Carolina Revenue Act
shall be subject to a privilege license tax at the maximum rate prescribed for
municipalities; except plumbers, heating contractors, and electricians shall be
charged at the rate of $25 per year.
   (c)   No license shall be issued for any business otherwise prohibited by
State statutes (i.e., G.S. 14-410.5 provides that it shall be unlawful for any
person to practice the art of phrenology, palmistry, clairvoyance, fortune
telling and other crafts of a similar kind in certain counties in the State).
   (d)   Non-Schedule B wholesale or retail businesses shall be taxed at the
rate of $25 per year (G.S. 160A-211).
   (e)   Barbershops or beauty salons shall be taxed at the rate of $2.50 per
barber, manicurist, cosmetologist, beautician or other operator employed in the
barbershop or beauty salon.
(G.S. 160A-211(b))
   (f)   Taxicabs shall be taxed at the rate of $15 per vehicle per year.
(G.S. 20-97)
   (g)   Alcoholic beverage businesses shall be taxed at the rate prescribed in
G.S. 105-113.73 and G.S. 105-113.78.
   (h)   Private clubs shall be taxed at the rate of $.50 per seat.
   (i)   Internet access/sweepstakes providers shall be taxed at an annual rate
of $2,500 for up to, but not exceeding, the first four machines or terminals
located in a business; and at an additional annual rate of $1,000 per machine
and/or terminal thereafter beyond the initial four machines or terminals.
(Ord. of 6/25/02; Amended by Ord. of 1/12/10; Amended by Ord. of 5/22/12)
ARTICLE C
Tax on Retail Short-Term Lease or Rental of Motor Vehicles
Section 2-4051 Tax established.
   The Town hereby imposes and levies a tax of 1.5% of the gross receipts from
the short-term lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public.
(Ord. of 11/5/01)
Section 2-4052 Administration.
   The County Tax Collector will administer and collect from operators of
leasing and rental establishments the taxes levied hereby, and the County may
promulgate additional rules and regulations necessary for implementation of the
taxes. The County shall remit the taxes collected on the Town's behalf to the
Town monthly after said taxes are collected.
(Ord. of 11/5/01)
Section 2-4053 Payment of taxes and filing of returns.
   The taxes levied hereby are due and payable to the County in monthly
installments on or before the fifteenth day of the month following the month in
which the tax accrues. Every taxable establishment required to collect the tax
shall, on or before the fifteenth day of each month, prepare and render a
return to the County. The County shall design, print, and furnish to all
taxable establishments the necessary forms for filing returns and instructions
to insure the full collection of the tax. A return filed for this purpose is
not a public record as defined by G.S. 132-1 and may not be disclosed except as
required by law.
(Ord. of 11/5/01)
Section 2-4054 Penalties.
   (a)   The enforcement of the tax will be governed by G.S. Chapter 105
Article 9. Included in this section is G.S. 105-236, which establishes
penalties. The penalty for failure to file a return when due is 5% of the tax
if the delay is not more than one month plus 5% for each additional month not
to exceed 25% of the tax or $5, whichever is greater (G.S. 105-236(3)). The
penalty for failure to pay a tax when due is 10% with a minimum of $5 (G.S.
105-237). The reason for the reduction or waiver must be stated in the minutes.
Interest shall be calculated by the Machinery Act rate of 0.75% a month or 9% a
year, for each month the tax is delinquent.
   (b)   Any person, firm, corporation or association who willfully attempts in
any manner to evade a tax imposed herein or who willfully fails to pay the tax
or make and file a return shall, in addition to the penalties provided by law
and herein, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided by law.
(Ord. of 11/5/01)
ARTICLE D
Disposal of Personal Property
Section 2-4061 Procedure.
   (a)   In accordance with G.S. 160A-266(c), the Town Manager is hereby
designated to declare surplus any personal property valued at less than $5,000
for any one item or group of items, to set its fair market value, and to convey
title to the property for the Town. The personal property may be either sold or
exchanged.
   (b)   On the first day of February of each year, the Town Manager shall
report in writing to the Mayor and Board of Aldermen on any property disposed
of under such authorization from July 1 through December 31 of the previous
year, and shall on the first day of August report in writing to the Mayor and
Board of Aldermen on any property disposed of under such authorization from
January 1 through July 30 of that year. The written report shall generally
describe the property sold or exchanged, and the amount of money or other
consideration received for each sale or exchange since the last such report
submitted.
(Ord. of 7/9/02)

2-5007   Reconciliation with federal income tax regulations.
Article B Social Security
(Reserved)
ARTICLE A
Employees Retirement Fund
Section 2-5001 Fund established; name.
   A retirement fund for the employees of the Town is hereby established under
the provisions and in accordance with Chapter 37 of the Session Laws of 1961,
which shall hereafter be known and referred to as the "Canton Employees
Retirement Plan."
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-78)
   Cross Reference: Chapter 37 of the 1961 Session Laws, authorizing the
establishment of the retirement fund, is included in this volume as a Related
Local Law, page L4.
   State Law Reference: Plan to be certified as actuarily sound by a qualified
actuary, G.S. 160A-163.
Section 2-5002 Membership in fund.
   Membership in the retirement fund shall include all classified employees of
the Town and the Town Manager.
(Code, 1963, Sec. 2-79) (Amended by Ord. of 1/1/76)
Section 2-5003 When benefits payable.
   Payment of benefits to employee members of the Canton Employees Retirement
Plan, or their beneficiaries, shall be in the case of retirement because of
age.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-80)
Section 2-5004 Benefits based on prior service.
   The benefits to be paid from the retirement fund shall be based partly upon
personal service rendered prior to the establishment of the fund by this
article. The contribution required to cover the cost of benefits based on prior
service shall be sufficient to fund the liability for such prior service in not
more than 40 years from the date of the establishment of such fund.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-81)
Section 2-5005 Tax shelter of employees contributions.
   The Town elects pursuant to the provisions of G.S. 128-30(b)(1) to pick up
and pay to the North Carolina Local Governmental Employees' Retirement System
the contributions which would be otherwise payable to this system by its
employees who are members of this system and to treat in all respects such
contributions in the manner specified in said G.S. 128-30(b)(1).
(Res. of 5-1-96)
Section 2-5006 Administration by Board; execution of contract and payment of
premiums.
   The retirement fund shall be administered by the Board and the Mayor is
hereby authorized and empowered to execute a contract for and on behalf of the
Town with an insurance company to put this plan into effect, and the Treasurer
of the Town is hereby authorized to pay the premiums on the fund in accordance
with the regular procedure of the Town.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-83)
   Editorial Note: The original ordinance authorizing the retirement plan was
enacted in 1961. Effective January 1, 1976, the Board adopted a new "Town of
Canton Employees' Retirement Plan." A first amendment to the 1976 Plan was
adopted 7/1/82. A second amendment to the Plan was adopted 1/14/86. A third
amendment to the Plan was adopted 5/11/93. A fourth amendment to the Plan was
adopted 11/23/93.
Section 2-5007 Reconciliation with federal income tax regulations.
   Notwithstanding any other contrary provision of the Plan, in calculating the
accrued benefit (including the right to any optional benefit provided under the
Plan) of any participant, such participant shall accrue no additional benefit
under the Plan on or after the first day of the Plan year beginning in 1989 to
the extent that such additional benefit accrual exceeds the benefit which would
otherwise accrue in accordance with the terms of the Plan as subsequently
amended to comply with those qualification requirements described in Income Tax
Regulations Section 1-401(b)-1(b)(2)(ii) (TRA '86). This provision shall be
effective until the end of the Plan Year beginning in 1989 and shall be
effective for such period if and only if the subsequent TRA '86 amendment is
made on or before that date.
(Ord. of 6/13/89)
ARTICLE B
Social Security
(Reserved)

ARTICLE A
General Administration
Section 2-6001 The Board of Aldermen.
   The Board of Aldermen shall make all appointments to the municipal service
coming within its statutory jurisdiction and shall authorize and approve the
pay plan for the municipal service.
   State Law Reference: Authority to adopt personnel rules and regulations,
G.S. 160A-164.
Section 2-6002 The Town Manager.
   The Town Manager shall serve as the Director of Personnel and be responsible
for the administration of the pay plan and of the personnel program, approve
all appointments to the classified service, excepting those positions which
come under the purview of the Board of Aldermen, prepare and recommend a
position classification system, prepare and recommend a pay plan for the
municipal service, advertise at his or her discretion, and where no applicants
for a position are available, all vacancies within the classified service,
maintain centralized personnel records and establish such training programs for
municipal employees as he or she may deem necessary and advisable.
Section 2-6003 The classified service.
   The classified service shall comprise all positions in the municipal
service, now existing or hereafter created, which shall fall under the direct
appointive authority of the Board of Aldermen and the Town Manager, with the
exception that any employee who is not employed on a full-time basis as a
regular employee by the Town of Canton shall not be included in the classified
service and shall not come under the provisions of this article. The position
of Town Manager shall not be included in the classified service.
Section 2-6004 through 2-6010 reserved.
ARTICLE B General Personnel Policies
Section 2-6011 Hours of work.
   The regular work week for the Town employees shall be 40 hours with the
exception of the Fire Department, Police Department and certain employees of
the Sanitation Department. The Fire and Police Departments shall submit for
approval a schedule of work for its employees to the Town Manager. Necessity
requires that some employees work at hours not hereby established and the said
employees' department head shall submit a list of employees not working regular
hours. A normal work day shall consist of eight (8) hours, normally worked
consecutively except for meals or other authorized interruptions. The normal
work week shall consist of five (5) consecutive days, usually Monday through
Friday. Public Safety Employees are subject to the Fair Labor Standards Act,
and are subject to change with Federal and State Law.
Section 2-6012 Legal holidays.
   (a)   Legal holidays observed by Town employees, unless such employees are
required to be on regular duty are:
   (1)   New Year's Day
   (2)   Easter Monday
   (3)   Memorial Day
   (4)   Independence Day
   (5)   Labor Day
   (6)   Thanksgiving Day
   (7)   Christmas Day
   (8)   The birthday of a full-time Town employee shall be observed as a
holiday by the said employee.
   (9)   Any other day or days as may be from time to time authorized by the
Board of Aldermen.
   (b)   When a holiday falls on Sunday, the following Monday shall be
observed. When a holiday falls on Saturday, one (1) day of annual leave shall
accrue to all employees.
Section 2-6013 Annual leave.
(a)
Length of Service     Vacation Leave Equiv.
1 through 4 years   12 work days
5 through 9 years   15 work days
10 through 14 years   18 work days
15 through 19 years   21 work days
20 through 24 years   24 work days
Length of Service     Vacation Leave Equiv.
25 through 29 years   27 work days
30 and over      Each additional 2 years service equals one additional leave
day
   (b)   Vacation leave may not be accrued in excess of 35 days.
   (c)   Vacation leave will be scheduled by the various department head so as
to meet the needs of the departments with due regard to the wishes of the
employees.
   (d)   If vacation leave is not taken within the time specified in this
section, or if accrued in amount exceeding the stipulated maximum, it shall be
forfeited and no financial compensation shall be paid.
   (e)   A regular employee with more than one (1) year of service whose
employment is terminated by reason of resignation, retirement, or death is
entitled to payment of unused leave. Any employee suspended or dismissed shall
not be entitled to compensation of unused leave.
Section 2-6014 Sick leave.
   (a)   Each regularly employed full-time employee shall earn sick leave at
the rate of one (1) day per month of service.
   (b)   Each regularly employed full-time employee shall earn sick leave at
the rate of one day for each calendar month of service. Sick leave is a benefit
granted to the employee in the event of sickness, injury, disability caused by
pregnancy or childbirth, serious illness in the immediate family, or in the
event of death in the immediate family. (Immediate family shall mean Father,
Mother, Sister, Brother, Grandfather, Grandmother, Children, Spouse, Father-in-
Law, Mother-in-Law).
   (Note: It is known that there will be some deaths or serious illnesses of a
relative that are not covered by the definitions above, but who in actuality
served the employee by raising him or her by living in the same house for a
number of years and being part of the family group. These cases will be
determined by the Town Manager on recommendation from the department head)
   (c)   Sick leave for more than three (3) days shall be granted only upon
submission to the Town Manager of a written statement from the physician in
attendance certifying as to the employees condition and his inability to be at
work.
   (d)   Any employee may be required to submit a medical certificate for any
sick leave taken. The department head will exercise judgment in this instance.
   (e)   A minimum of two (2) hours shall be given the department head in
requesting sick leave prior to the scheduled work day.
   (f)   Any employee who becomes ill while in a vacation status may, upon
presentation of a medical certificate by the attending physician, be granted
sick leave for the period of illness.
   (g)   Any employee who falsely reports himself to be on sick leave shall be
subject to disciplinary action and dismissal.
   (h)   Sick leave can accrue an unlimited number of days. Sick leave is lost
upon resignation. However, twenty percent of outstanding sick leave, with a
maximum of two months, is payable upon retirement or death.
Section 2-6015 Leave with pay.
   (a)   Leave with pay may be granted to employees who are required to serve
jury duty; provided that prior consent is obtained from the department head.
   (b)   Attendance at official meetings or conferences may be considered
regular work duty, where such attendance is deemed to be in the best interest
of the Town.
Section 2-6016 Leave without pay.
   A regularly employed full-time employee with at least two (2) years
continuous service with the Town may be granted without pay for a period not to
exceed one (1) year, for sickness, education, disability, maternity, military
service or other reasons deemed sufficient by the Town Manager. The leave may
be extended for a period of more than one (1) year if the request receives the
written approval of the Town Manager and department head. It should be noted
that in allowing or disallowing a request for any leave of absence, the needs
of the service must be met and if in the opinion of the department head and the
Town Manager the leave without pay will affect the department's operating
efficiency, then the request shall be denied.
Section 2-6017 Reserved.
Section 2-6018 Military leave.
   A regular full-time employee who is required to take military leave shall be
entitled to the leave. Where the employee is to be absent for a period of two
(2) weeks or less, the leave will be granted at no loss of compensation.
Military leave of more than two (2) weeks duration will be at no compensation.
The maximum number of days allowed from military leave with compensation shall
be 15 days in any one (1) year. In calculating compensation, the employee will
be required to submit a copy of his pay voucher from the military branch
requiring his presence and the compensation paid by the Town will be the
difference between the military pay and the employee's regular pay. If the
employee's military pay shall equal or exceed his regular pay, then the
employee shall receive no compensation for his military leave.
Section 2-6019 Training - educational policy.
   It shall be the policy of the Town of Canton to provide job related training
or schools as recommended by the Department Head and approved by the Town
Manager, for Town employees where such training or schools will clearly be in
the best interests of the Town. Such training or schools shall be provided at
the expense of the Town; however, in no event shall the Town provide such
employees with compensatory time off, or other means of compensation when such
job related training or schools is conducted after normal duty hours.
Section 2-6020 Travel and expense reimbursement.
   All regular full-time employees shall be reimbursed for travel and expenses
incurred in the course of their employment. To be eligible for such
reimbursement, however, the employee must have the approval of the Town
Manager. All reasonable expenses (e.g., transportation, meals, lodging, etc).
will be reimbursed at actual cost, while travel in a personal car will be
reimbursed at an approved rate per mile. Prior to such travel, the employee may
(at his discretion) receive an advance travel and expense allowance based upon
an approved per diem rate for such travel. The Town Manager shall be
responsible for the pricing for such travel advance and reimbursement
procedures on an appropriate travel expense/advance form. Such form(s) shall be
submitted to the Finance Office for advance travel and immediately following
such travel for reimbursement.
Section 2-6021 Outside employment.
   Any employee working at any job outside of his municipal employment shall
semi-annually submit a report to the Town Manager. These reports are to be made
so as to facilitate decisions with respect to possible conflict of interest or
adverse effect upon employee performance.
Section 2-6022 Medical examinations.
   (a)   All members of the classified service shall be required to undergo a
medical examination prior to reporting for work with the department. The
physician examining the employee must submit in writing a statement of the
physical condition of the employee to the Town Manager.
   (b)   Any and all employees may be required to undergo medical examinations
at periodic intervals at the discretion of the department head or the Town
Manager. In situations where service beyond the normal retirement age is
contemplated, annual physical examinations will be required.
Section 2-6023 Review of employee grievances.
   Any employee of the Town of Canton who believes that he has received
inequitable treatment because of some condition of his employment, may appeal
for relief from that condition of his employment. The chain-of-command shall
always prevail in these instances. The employee shall first take up his
grievance with his immediate supervisor. If the situation is not alleviated to
the satisfaction of the employee, then he may take the matter up with his
department head. If settlement cannot be achieved at this level, then employee
and the department head may take the grievance up with the Town Manager. The
Manager will take final action in such cases and report his findings to the
employee and supervisor. If any employee registers a grievance with his
supervisor, the supervisor is obligated to permit transmission of the grievance
through proper channels regardless of the supervisor's evaluation of the
validity of the grievance.
Section 2-6024 Employee prohibitions.
   (a)   No person in the classified service or seeking admission to the
classified service shall be appointed, promoted, demoted, removed or in any
other way be favored or discriminated against for political or religious
reasons. No employee shall seek or attempt to use any political endorsement in
connection with any appointment to, or preferment or advantage in connection
with any employment to, or preferment or advantage in connection with a
position in the classified service.
   (b)   No officer or employee in the classified service shall continue in
such position after being qualified as a candidate for nomination or election
to any public office.
   (c)   No town employee under the supervision of the Town Manager who has
supervisory responsibilities shall live more than 15 minutes' driving time of
the town limits.
(Ord. of 1/26/88)
   (d)   Violation of (a) or (b) above shall be grounds for dismissal or
rejection of any application.
Section 2-6025 through 2-6030 reserved.
ARTICLE C
Separation and Disciplinary Action
Section 2-6031 Retirement.
   Normally, an employee will retire on the last day of the month of the 65th
anniversary of his birthday. An employee can continue to work after this normal
retirement date. Of course, the Town of Canton can require an employee to
retire if he is not doing his job properly or the position requires bona fide
occupational qualifications. Benefit payments to participants on the retirement
plan will begin upon actual retirement.
Section 2-6032 Resignation.
   (a)   Any employee wishing to leave the classified service in good standing
shall submit a letter of resignation to his department head at least two (2)
weeks before leaving. The letter shall contain reasons for leaving the
classified service. Failure to comply with this procedure shall be just grounds
for denying compensation for any unused leave time. Unauthorized leave from
work for a period of three (3) consecutive days may be considered by a
department head as a resignation.
   (b)   All department heads shall transmit all resignations to the Town
Manger within 24 hours of receipt. Any employee leaving the classified service
in good standing shall be compensated for unused annual leave.
Section 2-6033 Dismissal.
   Any regular employee may be dismissed by his department head. The department
head shall notify the Town Manager in writing of any dismissal and the reason
therefor.
Section 2-6034 Demotion.
   Any regular employee may be demoted by his department head for inefficient
performance of duties, disciplinary reasons or other good cause. A written
statement shall be made by the department head to the Town Manager within 24
hours of any such action.
Section 2-6035 Suspension.
   Any regular employee may be suspended, without pay, by his department head
for disciplinary reasons. Suspension of any employee shall not exceed 30 days
within the calendar year. The department head shall notify the Town Manager of
any suspension, in writing, within 24 hours of the action. The department head
shall list the reasons for the suspension.
Section 2-6036 through 2-6040 reserved.
ARTICLE D
Change in Employees Status
Section 2-6041 Probationary period.
   The first six months of employment for any new employee of the Town shall be
regarded as a probationary period. The Town Manager has the option of extending
the probationary period for longer than six months at his discretion. This time
will be utilized in closely observing the employee's work and development and
for rejecting any employee whose work performance does not meet the required
work standards.
Section 2-6042 Transfer.
   Any vacant position may be filled by an employee of the Town where the
transfer is deemed to be in the best interest of the Town. The transfer shall
be for a probationary period of six (6) months and the employee being
transferred must have qualifications such as the vacant position needs. Any
employee transferred to a higher paying position must at the end of the
probationary period be performing satisfactory work in the new position. If
this is not the case, the employee shall return to his original position.
Section 2-6043 through 2-6050 reserved.
ARTICLE E
Compensation Rules
Section 2-6051 Appointment rate; salary of trainee.
   (a)   Pay and classification plan: All persons employed by the Town of
Canton shall be appointed at the minimum rate of pay as established for his
class; provided, however, that the employee may be placed in a "trainee" status
until such time that the employee can satisfactorily meet the minimum
requirements of the position. The appointment rate may be raised to the second
level only upon approval of the Town Manager at the written recommendation of
the department head. Such recommendation shall contain reasons for justifying
starting the employee at above the minimum rate. In cases of promotion,
employees will advance to the step above their present pay rate, disregarding
the minimum rate set for the new class. Upon the satisfactory completion of the
probationary period, a new employee, hired at the minimum rate, shall advance
to the second step of the pay range for his class. New employees hired at the
minimum step shall not advance to the third step within a period of less than
one year.
   (b)   Salary of trainee: A new employee who does not meet all of the
established qualifications for a position may be appointed with the approval of
the Town Manager at a "Training" salary at least one step below the minimum
salary established for that position classification. The employee shall
continue in this salary until the appointing department head with the approval
of Town Manager shall determine that the employee is qualified to assume the
responsibilities of the position. The salary of the employee shall then be
placed at the starting salary for the position classification.
Section 2-6052 Part-time work.
   When the need arises, the Town shall employ part-time employees. These
employees will be subject to Federal and State guidelines.
Section 2-6053 Pay rates in transfer; promotion or demotion.
   If an employee is transferred, promoted or demoted, his rate of pay shall be
determined as follows:
   (1)   If the rate of pay in the former class is less than the minimum rate
established for the class of the new position, the rate of pay shall be
advanced to the minimum of the class.
   (2)   If the rate of pay in the former class is greater than the maximum
rate established for the class of the new position, the pay shall be reduced to
the maximum rate or to an intermediate rate as determined by the Town Manager.
   (3)   If the rate of pay of the former class falls within the new range of
pay, and at an established increment in the range of the new class, the salary
rate shall remain the same in the case of transfer; in case of promotion it
shall be increased one (1) increment; in case of demotion it shall be reduced
one (1) increment.
   (4)   If the previous rate falls within the new range of pay but does not
correspond to an increment in the new range, then the rate of pay shall
increase to the next higher increment or reduced to the next lower increment,
according to whether it is a promotion, transfer or demotion.
   (5)   Solicitations by any company, firm, corporation, or agent shall not be
made during a regularly scheduled workday, nor shall solicitations be made on
Town property.
   (6)   Employees wishing to deduct any monthly payment from their paychecks
must first consult with the Accounting Department of the Town to determine if
deductions can be coordinated with our accounting procedure.
Section 2-6054 Overtime payment.
   Overtime work (in excess of 40 hours per work week) shall be paid on a one-
and one-half time basis. For any call back time, a minimum of two (2) hours
credit will be given to the employee.
(As amended by Ord. of 2/89)
Section 2-6055 through 2-6060 reserved.
ARTICLE F
Employees' Benefits
Section 2-6061 Social Security.
   The prescribed rates for Social Security are paid by the Town to match the
employees contribution.
Section 2-6062 Retirement; termination of health care and life insurance
benefits for retirees.
   (a)    Town has established a retirement system for all employees who have
completed one (1) year of credited service and attained age 25. The total cost
of the retirement plan is paid by the Town.
   (b)   Retired employees of the town who are receiving health care benefits
as provided in the resolution which became effective January 1, 1985, shall not
have their health care benefits terminated without there first being a public
hearing regarding same and all retired and full-time employees receiving health
care benefits being mailed notice of such public hearing.
(Ord. of 2/12/85)
   (c)   Retired employees of the town who are receiving life insurance
coverage as provided in the resolution which became effective November 1, 1986,
shall not have their life insurance coverage terminated without there first
being a public hearing regarding same and all retired and full-time employees
receiving life insurance coverage being mailed notice of the public hearing.
(Ord. of 10/28/86, Sec. 1)
Section 2-6063 Health dental, life and accident insurance.
   The Town maintains a health dental, life and accident insurance policy on
each employee after the employee works one month. The total cost of the policy
is paid for by the Town.
Section 2-6064 Uniforms.
   In most departments, uniforms are furnished for the employees. The total
cost of these uniforms is paid for by the Town.
Section 2-6065 Public Safety Departments.
   In cases where Public Safety Departments have policy booklets established
and adopted for those departments, the Personnel Rules and Regulations as
adopted by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen shall coincide and supersede these
departmental policy booklets.
Section 2-6066 Workmen's compensation.
   Workmen's compensation benefits will be paid to any employee who is involved
in a job related accident, and who, only through a doctor's orders, is unable
to return to work in less than seven (7) days. Each employee may build an
indefinite number of days of sick leave and will draw full wages in addition to
workmen's compensation. Annual leave and sick leave continue to accrue during
the entire illness.
Section 2-6067 Insurance accident and sickness benefits.
   Insurance accident and sickness benefits will be paid to any employee who is
absent from work from a nonjob-related accident or illness. Each employee may
build an indefinite number of days of sick leave and will draw full wages in
addition to accident and sickness benefits paid by the Town's insurance
company. This is an incentive to build as many sick leave days as possible for
use in the event of a long-term illness.
Section 2-6068 Health care and life insurance for retirees.
   (a)   An employee who retires according to the Town of Canton Employees'
Retirement Plan requirements, with at least 15 years permanent active Town
employment will receive health care insurance paid by the Town, for said
employee for the remainder of his or her lifetime and for his or her spouse
until spouse reaches age 70. Should an employee retire on disability with at
least five years permanent active Town employment, health care insurance will
be provided by the Town for said employee for the remainder of his or her
lifetime and for his or her dependents until age 19 or until age 25 if a full-
time student, and for his or her spouse until age 70.
   (b)   An employee who retires according to the Canton Employees' Retirement
Plan requirements, with at least 15 years permanent active Town employment will
receive life insurance paid by the Town according to the following schedule for
the remainder of his or her lifetime:
   Under age 70            to 50%
   At or after age 70         to 10% of original amount, but not less than
$1,000.
(Ord. of 10/10/89; Ord. of 10/10/89; as amended by Ord. of 4-1-91; as amended
by Ord. of 4-1-91)
Section 2-6069 Dental care benefits to employees who retire.
   (A)   An employee who retires according to the Town of Canton Employees'
Retirement Plan requirements, with at least 15 years permanent active Town
employment will receive dental care insurance paid by the Town, for said
employee for the remainder of his or her lifetime; and
   (B)   Should an employee retire on disability with at least five years
permanent active Town employment, dental care insurance will be provided by the
Town for said employee for the remainder of his or her lifetime.
(Ord. of 5/13/97)
Section 2-6070 through 20-6079 reserved.
ARTICLE G
Merit System
Section 2-6080 Principles.
   The Town of Canton embraces the following merit system principles in
administering its personnel program:
   (a)   Applicants and employees shall be assured of fair treatment in all
aspects of personnel administration without regard for political affiliation,
religious creed, sex, national origin, color or race. Individuals shall
likewise be treated with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional
rights as citizens.
   (b)   Employees shall be recruited, selected, trained and advanced on the
basis of their relative ability, knowledge, and skill.
   (c)   Employees shall be retained on the basis of the adequacy of their
performance. They shall be guided in ways to correct inadequate performance and
separated when inadequate performance cannot be corrected.
   (d)   Employees shall be protected against coercion for partisan political
purposes.
   (e)   Employees shall receive equitable and adequate pay and benefits and
eligible employees shall receive merit pay increases based on the quality of
their performance, subject to the availability of funds.
Section 2-6081 Merit Salary Increases.
   Pay increases of one-half step or one whole step on the applicable salary
grade may be granted to deserving regular full-time employees in accordance
with the following provisions:
   (a)   When the employees holds a permanent appointment with the Town, i.e.,
the employee satisfactorily complete the required probationary period.
   (b)   When such an increase will not exceed the maximum salary rate for the
class of his position.
   (c)   When a year of continuous service has elapsed.
   (d)   When the work of the employee exceeds the standards established for
satisfactory performance, but is below outstanding performance, the employee
may be recommended for a half-step merit increase.
   (e)   When the work of the employee is determined to be outstanding on a
continuing basis, the employee may be recommended for a whole step merit
increase.
   (f)   When the employee is recommended for a merit salary increase (half-
step or whole step) by his department head it shall be the responsibility of
the department to periodically (at least annually) counsel with his employees
with regard to work quality and quantity, dependability, attitude, attendance
and punctuality, and to suggest ways and means of improving same (where
appropriate). The Town Manager shall be responsible for establishing an
appropriate system for implementing this merit provision and to see that it is
carried out in a responsible manner.
