ARTICLE A
Recreation Commission
Section 2-7001 Commission created.
   There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Recreation
Commission of Canton, North Carolina.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-8)
   State Law Reference: Specific authority to create commission, G.S. 160A-354.
Parks and Recreation in general, G.S. 160A, Article 18.
Section 2-7002 Composition; appointment of members.
   The recreation commission shall be composed of ten (10) members to be
appointed by the Board of Aldermen.
Section 2-7003 Terms of members; vacancies.
   (a)   Members appointed to the commission shall serve for a term of two
years and until their successors are appointed and qualified, except for the
term of the member who represents the Board which shall automatically terminate
at any time his affiliation with such unit ends.
   (b)   Vacancies in the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by
the Board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-10; Amended by Ord. of 3/22/94)
Section 2-7004 Members to serve without compensation.
   The members of the commission shall serve without compensation.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-12)
Section 2-7005 Meetings; officers.
   (a)   The commission shall hold regular meetings at such times and places as
it may designate.
   (b)   The commission shall appoint from its membership a chairman and such
other officers as it may deem necessary for the orderly conduct of its
business.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-13, 14-14)
Section 2-7006 General powers and duties.
   The recreation commission shall provide, maintain, operate and supervise the
public parks, playgrounds, athletic fields and recreation centers and other
recreational facilities owned or controlled by the Town, or leased or loaned to
the commission by the owners thereof. The commission shall have complete
supervision of the facilities and activities provided and conducted on or in
connection with the parks, playgrounds, athletic fields and recreation centers
and shall have the power to conduct any form of recreational or cultural
activity. Such powers as are provided by State statute or by ordinances of the
Town relating to the development and operation of recreation systems, parks and
playgrounds are hereby vested in the recreation commission to be exercised by
it subject to any and all restrictions contained in such statutes and
ordinances.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-15)
Section 2-7007 Change; modification of powers.
   The powers and authority granted by this article to the recreation
commission may be changed, altered, modified or amended by the Board at any
time in its discretion.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-16)
Section 2-7008 By-laws, rules and regulations.
   The recreation commission may adopt bylaws, rules and regulations covering
its procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code and applicable
State laws. The commission shall, from time to time, make rules and regulations
governing the operation and conduct of the recreational facilities operated by
the commission.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-17)
Section 2-7009 Appointment of director of recreation and other employees.
   The recreation commission shall have power to appoint and designate a
director of recreation who possesses the necessary foundation training and who
demonstrates by actual work his ability to organize and direct a community
recreation system. Such other trained persons as may be necessary in the
maintenance and operation of the recreation facilities and system may be
employed by the commission.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-18)
Section 2-7010 Acceptance and use of grants, gifts, and bequests.
   The recreation commission may accept any grant, gift, bequest or donation of
any personal property offered or made for recreational purposes and, with the
approval of the Board may accept any grant, gift or devise of real estate. Any
gift or bequest of money or other personal property or grant or devise of real
estate shall be held, used and finally disposed of in accordance with the terms
or conditions under which such grant, gift or devise is made and accepted.
(Code 1963, Sec. 19-19)
Section 2-7011 Limitation on right to contract or incur obligations.
   The recreation commission shall have no authority to enter into any contract
or incur any obligations binding upon the town other than the current
obligations or contracts to be fully executed within the current fiscal year
and all within the budget appropriations made by the Mayor and Board of
Aldermen.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-20)
Section 2-7012 Disbursing funds budgeted to or received by commission;
accounting for funds received.
   Funds appropriated by the Board of Aldermen and budgeted to the recreation
commission shall be disbursed by the fiscal disbursing officer of the Town upon
vouchers issued by the recreation commission and approved by the Board and
within the budget appropriations made. Funds received by the recreation
commission from operation of the playgrounds and recreation system and from
other sources shall be paid to the treasurer of the Town to the credit and use
of the commission and disbursed as budget funds are disbursed, except that
funds received by gift, bequest, grant or devise shall be disbursed in
accordance with the terms of such gift or bequest. Funds collected by the
commission shall be paid to the Town treasurer weekly, and a report of the
collections filed with the Board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-21)
Section 2-7013 Reports to Board.
   The recreation commission shall make full and complete reports to the Board
at least quarterly and at such other times as may be requested to by the Board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-22)
Section 2-7014 Submission of estimated budget to the Board.
   The recreation commission shall submit to the Board its estimated budget for
each fiscal year, setting out in detail the estimated expenses and estimated
receipts from the operation of the recreational facilities and other sources.
Such proposed budget shall be submitted by the end of each fiscal year.
(Code 1963, Sec. 14-23)
Section 2-7015 through 2-7020 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Planning Board
Section 2-7021 Established; composition; appointment of members.
   (a)   There is hereby established a planning board for the Town, which board
shall consist of not less than four members nor more than nine members
appointed by the Board of Aldermen, who shall be residents of the Town.
   (b)   In addition, the planning board shall consist of four members who
reside outside the Town but within its extraterritorial jurisdiction as
established in an "Ordinance Establishing Extraterritorial Jurisdiction
Boundaries." The Haywood County Board of Commissioners shall appoint three
members. One member shall be a resident of the Haywood County portion of the
Rough Creek extraterritorial jurisdiction and one member shall be a resident of
the extraterritorial jurisdiction located in the Pigeon River watershed, and
one member shall be a resident of the extraterritorial jurisdiction located in
the Asheville Highway ETJ. The Buncombe County Board of Commissioners shall
appoint one member who shall be a resident of the Buncombe County portion of
the Rough Creek extraterritorial jurisdiction. However, in the event either
County Board of Commissioners is unable to find a resident of its portion of
the extraterritorial jurisdiction who is willing to serve on the planning
board, it shall appoint any resident of the respective county to serve on the
board. Appointments by the County Boards of Commissioners shall be for five-
year terms.
(Ord. of 9/15/87; Amended by Ord. of 9/14/93; Amended by Ord. 7/22/97; Amended
by Ord. of 6/24/21)
State Law Reference: Establishment of planning board; duties, G.S. 160D-301.
Section 2-7022 Terms of members; vacancies; oath of office.
   The members of the planning board shall be appointed for terms of three
years. Vacancies occurring for reasons other than expiration of terms shall be
filled as they occur for the period of the unexpired term. All members
appointed to the Planning Board shall, before entering their duties, qualify by
taking an oath of office.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-52; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7023 Officers.
   The planning board shall elect a chairman and create and fill such offices
as it may determine to be necessary. The term of the chairman and other
officers shall be one year, with eligibility for re-election. The chairman and
other officers shall be residents of the Town of Canton.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-53; Amended by Ord. of 9/15/87; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7024 Conflict of interest.
   Members of the Planning Board shall not vote on any advisory or legislative
decision regarding a development regulation adopted pursuant to this article
where the outcome of the matter being considered is reasonably likely to have a
direct, substantial, and readily identifiable financial impact on the member.
An appointed board member shall not vote on any zoning amendment if the
landowner of the property subject to a rezoning petition or the applicant for a
text amendment is a person with whom the member has a close familial, business,
or other associational relationship.
(Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7025 Meetings generally.
   The planning board shall hold at least one meeting monthly, and all of its
meetings shall be open to the public. The Planning Board shall keep minutes of
board proceedings. A majority of the membership of the planning board eligible
to vote shall be a quorum for the purpose of taking any official action
required by this article. The members of the board representing the
extraterritorial jurisdiction shall have equal rights, duties and privileges
with other members of the board except in those matters dealing exclusively
with property inside the corporate limits of the Town, in which case the
extraterritorial representative shall have no authority to vote regardless of
whether or not the extraterritorial representatives have authority to vote.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-54; Amended by Ord. of 9/15/87; Amended by Ord. of 9/14/93;
Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7026 Attendance at meetings.
   Faithful attendance at the meetings of the planning board shall be
considered a prerequisite for the maintenance of membership on the board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-55; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7027 Powers and duties generally.
   It shall be the function and duty of the planning board to make
comprehensive surveys and studies on existing conditions and probable future
developments and prepare such plans for physical, social, and economic growth
as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience or the
general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the development of the
town. In general, the planning board shall have the power and duty to:
   (1)   Acquire and maintain in current form such basic information, and
materials as are necessary to an understanding of past trends, present
conditions, and forces at work to cause changes in these conditions;
   (2)   Prepare and from time to time amend and revise a comprehensive and
coordinated plan for the physical development of the area;
   (3)   Establish principles and policies for guiding action in the
development of the area;
   (4)   Prepare and recommend to the Town Board ordinances promoting orderly
development in accordance with the comprehensive plan;
   (5)   Determine whether specific proposed developments conform to the
principles and requirements of the comprehensive plan for the growth and
improvement of the area, including, but not limited to, review and comment on
all zoning text and map amendments as required by G.S. 160D-604;
   (6)   To provide a preliminary forum for review of quasi -judicial
decisions, provided that no part of the forum or recommendation may be used as
a basis for the deciding board; and
   (7)   Keep the Town Board and the general public informed and advised as to
these matters.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-56; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7028 Basic studies by Board.
   The planning board may collect maps and aerial photographs of man-made and
natural physical features of the area, statistics on past trends and present
conditions with respect to population, property values, the economic base of
the area, land use, and other such information as is important or likely to be
important in the preparation of a comprehensive plan of development for the
planning area and its various parts. In addition, the planning board may make
special studies on the location, condition, and adequacy of specific
facilities, which may include but are not limited to studies of housing;
commercial and industrial facilities; parks, playgrounds and recreational
facilities; public and private utilities; and traffic transportation and
parking facilities.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-57; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7029 Comprehensive plan-generally.
   (a)   The comprehensive plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts, and
descriptive matter, shall be and show the planning board's recommendations to
the Town Board for the development of the planning area, including, among other
things, the general location, character and extent of streets, bridges,
boulevards, parkways, playgrounds, squares, parks, aviation fields, and other
public ways, grounds and open spaces; the general location and extent of public
utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for
water, light, sanitation, transportation, communication, power and other
purposes; the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment,
change of use, or extension of any of the foregoing ways, buildings, grounds,
open spaces, property, utilities, or terminals; the most desirable pattern of
land use within the area, including areas for residential uses, for farming and
forestry, for manufacturing and industrial uses, for commercial uses, for
recreational uses, for open spaces, for mixed uses and for other features.
   (b)   The plan and any ordinances or other measures to effectuate it shall
be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated,
adjusted, and harmonious development of the town and its environs which will,
in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety,
morals and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the
process of development, including, among other things, adequate provision for
traffic, the promotion of safety from fire and other dangers, adequate
provision for light and air, the promotion of healthful and convenient
distribution of population, the promotion of good civic design and
arrangements, wise and efficient expenditure of public funds, and the adequate
provision of public utilities, services and other public requirements.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-58; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7030 Public hearings on the comprehensive plan.
   Comprehensive plans shall be adopted by the Town Board of Aldermen with the
advice and consultation of the planning board. Adoption and amendment of a
comprehensive plan is a legislative decision and shall follow the process
mandated for zoning text amendments set by G.S. 160D-601. The planning board
may conduct such public hearings as required to gather information necessary
for the drafting, establishment, and maintenance of the comprehensive plan.
Before adopting any such plan the Town shall hold at least one (1) public
hearing thereon.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-58; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
   Cross Reference: The Town zoning ordinance is Part 9, Chapter 4.
   State Law Reference: Zoning regulations are authorized by G.S. 160D-702.
Section 2-7031 Powers and duties relative to zoning ordinance.
   (a)   The planning board shall prepare and submit a zoning ordinance and
maps to the Town Board for its consideration and possible adoption in
accordance with the provisions of Chapter 160D of the General Statutes of North
Carolina. The planning board may initiate, from time to time, proposals for
amendment of the zoning ordinance, based upon its studies and the comprehensive
plan. In addition, it shall review and make recommendations to the Town Board
concerning all proposed amendments to the zoning ordinance.
   (b)   When conducting a review of proposed zoning text or map amendments
pursuant to this section, the planning board shall advise and comment on
whether the proposed action is consistent with any comprehensive plan that has
been adopted and any other officially adopted plan that is applicable. The
planning board shall provide a written recommendation to the governing board
that addresses plan consistency and other matters as deemed appropriate by the
planning board, but a comment by the planning board that a proposed amendment
is inconsistent with the comprehensive plan shall not preclude consideration or
approval of the proposed amendment by the governing board. If a zoning map
amendment qualifies as a "large-scale rezoning" under G.S. 160D-602(b), the
planning board statement describing plan consistency may address the overall
rezoning and describe how the analysis and policies in the relevant adopted
plans were considered in the recommendation made.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-60; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7032 Powers and duties relative to subdivision regulations.
   The planning board shall prepare and submit subdivision regulations to the
Town Board for its consideration and adoption and the planning board shall
administer such regulations after their adoption.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-61; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7033 Appointment of committees and employees; authorizing
expenditures.
   The planning board is authorized to appoint such committees and employees,
and to authorize such expenditures as it may see fit, subject to limitations of
funds provided for the planning board by the Town Board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-62; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7034 Receipt and disbursement of contributions.
   The planning board is authorized to receive contributions from private
agencies and organizations or from individuals, in addition to any sums which
may be appropriated for its use by the Town Board. It may accept and disburse
such contributions for special purposes or projects, subject to any specific
conditions which it deems acceptable, whether or not such projects are included
in the approved budget.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-63; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7035 Right of entry.
   The planning board or its agents may, in the performance of its official
duties, enter upon lands and make examinations or surveys and maintain
necessary monuments thereon.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-64; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7036 Authority relative to publicity and education.
   The planning board shall have power to promote public interest in and an
understanding of its recommendations, and to that end it may publish and
distribute copies of its recommendations and may employ such other means of
publicity and education as it may determine.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-65; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7037 Attendance by members and employees at planning conferences.
   Members or employees of the planning board, when duly authorized by the
planning board, may attend planning conferences or meetings of planning
institutes or hearings upon pending planning legislation, and the planning
board may, by formal and affirmative vote, pay, within the planning board's
budget, the reasonable traveling expenses incidental to such attendance.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-66; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7038 Rules and records.
   The planning board shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business and
shall keep a record of its members' attendance and of its resolutions,
discussions, finding, and recommendations, which record shall be a public
record.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-67; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7039 Annual report and budget request to Town Board.
   The planning board shall annually submit to the Town Board a written report
of its activities, an analysis of the expenditures to date for the current
fiscal year, and its requested budget of funds needed for operation during the
ensuing fiscal year.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-68; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7040 Duty of Town officials to furnish information to board.
   All town officials shall, upon request, furnish to the planning board such
available records or information as it may require in its work.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-69; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7041 Chairman, secretary to serve as ex-officio members of County
Planning Board.
   It shall be the duty of the chairman and secretary of the Canton Planning
Board to serve as ex-officio members of the Haywood County Planning Board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 2-70; Amended by Ord. of 6/24/21)
Section 2-7042 through 2-7050 reserved.
ARTICLE C
Section 2-7051 through 2-7060 reserved.
ARTICLE D
Other Boards and Commissions
Section 2-7061 Board of Elections.
   The Town Board of Elections, consisting of three members, is appointed by
the Town Board of Aldermen, to serve permanent terms. Their primary function is
to uphold Federal, State and Local election laws in the Town of Canton.
   Cross Reference: Election Board, Ch. 131, Priv. L. 1935, as amended, see
Related Local Laws, page L-3.
Section 2-7062 Zoning Board of Adjustment.
   There are five corporate members on the Zoning Board of Adjustment and four
extraterritorial jurisdiction members. Initial corporate members are appointed
for staggered three-year terms. ETJ members, two members representing the
Critical Area of the Rough Creek Watershed (one appointed by Buncombe County
and one appointed by Haywood County), one member representing the Critical Area
of the Pigeon River Watershed and one member representing the Asheville Highway
ETJ, are appointed by the County Board of Commissioners and their appointments
shall be for three-year terms. The function of this Board is to vote on any
reversal or decision of the Building Inspector or variation of any zoning
ordinance. Detailed duties and Board composition are listed in this Code, Part
9, Chapter 5.
(Amended by Ord. 7/22/97)
Section 2-7063 Repealed.
   Editorial Note: Section
2-7063 concerning the Housing Authority, was repealed by an ordinance passed 9/
9/80.
Section 2-7064 Historical Commission.
   (a)   Establishment; composition. The Canton Historical Commission, composed
of 11 members serving 2-year terms, was formed to collect, preserve and record
all major historical events that have had an impact on the Town of Canton.
Documents and artifacts in the possession of the Commission are available to
the general public for purposes of exhibition or study.
(Ord. of 1/23/90)
   (b)   Qualification of members.
   (1)   Members are not required to reside inside the Town limits.
   (2)   Where possible, appointments to the Commission shall be made in such a
manner as to maintain at all times a majority of members who have an interest
or have had special training or experience in historical preservation,
conservation, architecture, records retention, or a closely related field.
   (c)   Term of members.
   (1)   Members shall be appointed by the Board of Alderman, and shall serve
for a term of two years or until they are reappointed. The Board of Alderman
shall appoint the Chairman, who shall serve at the pleasure of the Board. The
ex-officio member who represents the Board of Alderman shall serve for the
duration of his or her term on the Board of Alderman or a replacement is named.
   (2)   Vacancies occurring for reasons other than the expiration of terms
shall be filled as they occur for the period of the unexpired term.
   (d)   Compensation of members. Members of the Commission shall serve without
pay, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incidental to the performance of
their duties, within the limits of funds available to the Commission. In all
cases, any such reimbursement shall only be made in accordance with policies
approved by the Board of Aldermen.
   (e)   Organization; rules; meetings; records.
   (1)   Within 30 days after its appointment, the Commission shall meet and
elect such officers as it may deem necessary for the orderly conduct of its
business. The term of the chair and other officers shall be one year with
eligibility for reelection.
   (2)   The Commission shall hold regular meetings at such times and places as
it may designate. The Commission shall hold at least six meetings per year.
   (3)   The Commission shall adopt rules to govern the conduct of its meetings
based upon Robert’s Rules of Order.
   (4)   The Commission shall keep a record of its members’ attendance and of
its resolutions, discussions, findings and recommendations, which shall be open
to the public. A copy of the minutes of each meeting shall be filed with the
Town Clerk and Board of Aldermen.
   (5)   All Commission meetings shall be open to the public.
   (6)   For the purpose of taking any official action authorized or required
there shall be present a quorum of six members.
   (f)   Powers and duties of the Commission. It shall be the purpose of the
Commission to carry out the historic preservation objectives promulgated by the
Town’s governing body. To that end, the Commission shall have the following
powers:
   (1)   Formulate ideas and concepts for historic preservation programs,
projects, and plans; and to present recommendations to the Board of Aldermen
for approval.
   (2)   Initiate, promote and assist in the implementation of programs of
historic significance in the Town, as approved by the Board of Aldermen.
   (3)   Oversee, coordinate and implement the historic preservation programs
that will preserve buildings, records, documents, photographs, and other items
of historical significance.
   (4)   Seek to coordinate the activities of individuals, agencies, and
organizations, public and private, whose plans, activities and programs affect
the historic aspects affecting the Town.
   (5)   Provide leadership and guidance in matters of renovation, design and
appearance to individuals, and to public and private organizations, and
agencies seeking to preserve items of historical significance.
   (6)   Make studies of the historical characteristics of the Town, including
surveys and inventories of an appropriate nature, and recommend any project to
be undertaken.
   (7)   Gather, collect, copy inventory, catalogue, and preserve or record
items of historical significance.
   (8)   Request from the proper officials of any public or private agency or
body, including agencies of the state and its political subdivisions, its
records of buildings, facilities, documents, photographs, or materials of
historic significance located within the Town.
   (9)   Formulate and recommend to the Board of Aldermen the adoption or
amendment of ordinances, including the Zoning Ordinance, subdivision
regulations, and other local ordinances regulating the use of property, that
will, in the opinion of the Commission, serve to enhance the historic
preservation of the Town.
   (10)   Promote the display of any article or item of historical significance
for educational purposes.
   (11)   Promote public interest in and an understanding of its history, and
to that end to conduct exhibitions and displays as well as prepare, publish,
and distribute to the public those studies and reports in the opinion of the
Commission, advance the cause of historic preservation and education.
   (g)   Annual report; budget requests.
   (1)   The Board of Aldermen may appropriate such funds as it deems necessary
to carry out the purposes for which the Commission was created.
   (2)   The Commission shall, no later than April 15 of each year, submit in
writing to the Town Manager and Board of Aldermen a written report of its
activities, a statement of its expenditures to date for the current fiscal
year, and its requested budget for the next fiscal year.
   (3)   The Commission shall have no authority to incur any financial
obligation or liability in the name of the Town without first having obtained
the consent and approval of the Board of Aldermen. All accounts and funds of
the Commission shall be administered in accordance with the requirements of the
Local Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act.
   (4)   The Commission is authorized to receive contributions from private
agencies, foundations, organizations, individuals, the state or federal
governments, or any other source, in addition to any sums which may be
appropriated for its use by the Board of Aldermen.
   (5)   The Commission may request from the Board of Aldermen suitable
arrangements for the procurement or provision of staff or technical services of
the Commission.
(Ord. of 5/26/02)
   Editorial Note: Ord. of 1/23/90 changed Commission's membership from seven
to eleven members, retroactive to February 14, 1989.
Sec. 2-7065   Repealed.
   Editorial Note: Section
2-7065 concerning the Citizens Advisory Board was repealed by an ordinance
passed 3/22/94.
Section 2-7066 Uplift Committee.
   There shall be established a Town "Uplift Committee" composed of 13 members,
each serving a three-year term.
Section 2-7067 Retirement Plan Committee.
   A Group Annuity Contract was originally established on August 29, 1961 to
provide retirement benefits for the Town's employees. By ordinance, the Board
of Aldermen amended the Group Annuity Contract and established The Town of
Canton Employees' Retirement Plan with, an effective date of January 1, 1976.
The Retirement Committee consists of the Mayor, the Town Manager and one
additional member appointed by the Board of Aldermen. The Committee shall
perform all administrative duties and responsibilities as set forth in section
8 of the plan. The Trustees (Mayor and Town Manager) must invest, administer,
and care for the funds contributed to the plan from any and all sources.
Section 2-7068 Labor Day Commission.
   (a)   A Labor Day Commission is hereby established to be responsible for
planning and overseeing activities for the Canton Labor Day Ceremony.
   (b)   The Labor Day Commission shall be comprised of six members to serve
two year terms. Members of other boards will be given first priority for
selection to this Commission.
   (c)   A budget shall be established by the Labor Day Commission and the
Commission shall have the financial responsibility of the Labor Day activities.
   (d)   The Commission shall establish policies, rules, and regulations and
shall recommend to the Board of Aldermen any ordinance necessary to carry out
the Labor Day activities.
   (e)   The Commission may secure voluntary help from other organizations,
agencies, or individuals and see that the necessary insurance and bonds are in
place for all activities or agencies participating in Labor Day.
(Ord. of 8/10/93; Amended by Ord. of 3/22/94; Amended by Ord. of 3/27/96)
Section 2-7069 through 2-7070 reserved.
ARTICLE E
Advisory Community Appearance Commission
Section 2-7071 Establishment; composition.
   There is hereby created an advisory commission to be known as the Town of
Canton Community Appearance Commission, which shall consist of nine members
appointed by the Board of Aldermen. In addition to the nine members, the
Commission shall have two non-voting Ex-Officio members, one of which shall be
selected from the Board of Aldermen and the other one selected by the Canton
Papertown Association.
(Ord. of 1/26/93; Amended by Ord. of 3/22/94; Amended by Ord. of 3/6/96)
Section 2-7072 Qualifications of members.
   (a)   Seven members are required to reside inside the Town limits. Two
members can live outside of Canton, one of which shall be a Canton business
person.
   (b)   Where possible, appointments to the Commission shall be made in such a
manner as to maintain at all times a majority of members who have had special
training or experience in a design field, such as architecture, landscape,
horticulture, city planning or a closely related field.
(Ord. of 1/26/93; Amended by Ord. of 3/6/96)
Section 2-7073 Terms of members.
   (a)   Members shall serve for a term of two years or until they are
reappointed. The member who represents the Board of Aldermen shall serve for
the duration of his or her term on the Board of Aldermen or replacement named.
   (b)   Vacancies occurring for reasons other than the expiration of terms
shall be filled as they occur for the period of the unexpired term.
(Ord. of 1/26/93; Amended by Ord. of 3/22/94)
Section 2-7074 Compensation of members.
   Members of the Commission shall serve without pay, but may be reimbursed for
actual expenses incidental to the performance of their duties, within the
limits of funds available to the Commission. In all cases, any such
reimbursement shall only be made in accordance with policies approved by the
Board of Aldermen.
(Ord. of 1/26/93)
Section 2-7075 Organization; rules; meetings; records.
   (a)   Within 30 days after its appointment, the Commission shall meet and
elect a Chair and such other officers as it may deem necessary for the orderly
conduct of its business. The term of the Chair and other officers shall be one
year with eligibility for reelection.
   (b)   The Commission shall hold regular meetings at such times and places as
it may designate. The Commission shall hold at least six meetings per year.
   (c)   The Commission shall adopt rules to govern the conduct of its
business.
   (d)   The Commission shall keep a record of its members' attendance and of
its resolutions, discussions, findings and recommendations, which shall be open
to the public. A copy of the minutes of each meeting shall be filed with the
Board of Aldermen and the Planning Board.
   (e)   All Commission meetings shall be open to the public.
   (f)   For the purpose of taking any official action authorized or required,
there shall be present a quorum of five members.
(Ord. of 1/26/93)
Section 2-7076 Powers and duties of Commission.
   It shall be the purpose of the Commission to carry out the beautification
objectives promulgated by the Town's governing body. To that end, the
Commission shall have the following powers:
   (a)   Formulate ideas and concepts for beautification programs and present
recommendations to the Board of Aldermen for approval;
   (b)   Initiate, promote and assist in the implementation of programs of
general community beautification in the Town, as approved by the Board of
Aldermen;
   (c)   Oversee, coordinate and implement the streetscape program which shall
include flower beds, Christmas lighting, gazebo and all beautification projects
in the future;
   (d)   Seek to coordinate the activities of individuals, agencies, and
organizations, public and private, whose plans, activities and programs bear
upon the appearance of the Town;
   (e)   Provide leadership and guidance in matters of area or community design
and appearance to individuals, and to public and private organizations, and
agencies;
   (f)   Make studies of the visual characteristics and problems of the Town,
including surveys and inventories of an appropriate nature, and recommend
standards and policies of design for the entire area, any portion or
neighborhood thereof, or any project to be undertaken;
   (g)   Prepare both general and specific plans for the improved appearance of
the Town. These plans may include the entire area or any part thereof and may
include private as well as public property. The plans shall set forth desirable
standards and goals for the aesthetic enhancement of the Town or any part
thereof including public ways and areas, open spaces, and public and private
buildings and projects;
   (h)   Request from the proper officials of any public agency or body,
including agencies of the state and its political subdivisions, its plans for
public buildings, facilities, or projects to be located within the Town;
   (i)   Review these plans and make recommendations regarding their aesthetic
suitability to the appropriate agency, or to the Board of Aldermen. All plans
shall be reviewed by the Commission in a prompt and expeditious manner, and all
recommendations of the Commission with regard to any public project shall be
made in writing. Copies of the recommendation shall be transmitted promptly to
the Planning Board or the Board of Aldermen and to the appropriate agency;
   (j)   Formulate and recommend to the Board of Aldermen the adoption or
amendment of ordinances (including the Zoning Ordinance, subdivision
regulations, and other local ordinances regulating the use of property) that
will, in the opinion of the Commission, serve to enhance the appearance of the
Town;
   (k)   Direct the attention of Town officials to needed enforcement of any
ordinance that may in any way affect the appearance of the Town;
   (l)   Seek voluntary adherence to the standards and policies of its plans;
   (m)   Promote public interest in and an understanding of its
recommendations, studies, and plans, and to that end to prepare, publish, and
distribute to the public those studies and reports as will, in the opinion of
the Commission, advance the cause of improved Town appearance;
   (n)   Conduct public meetings and hearings as needed.
(Ord. of 1/26/93)
Section 2-7077 Annual report; budget requests; funding; staff.
   (a)   The Board of Aldermen may appropriate such funds as it deems necessary
to carry out the purposes for which the Commission was created.
   (b)   The Commission shall, no later than April 15 of each year, submit in
writing to the Town Manager and Board of Aldermen a written report of its
activities, a statement of its expenditures to date for the current fiscal
year, and its requested budget for the next fiscal year.
   (c)   The Commission shall have no authority to incur any financial
obligation or liability in the name of the Town without first having obtained
the consent and approval of the Board of Aldermen. All accounts and funds of
the Commission shall be administered in accordance with the requirements of the
Local Government Budget and fiscal Control Act.
   (d)   The Commission is authorized to receive contributions from private
agencies, foundations, organizations, individuals, the state or federal
governments, or any other source, in addition to any sums which may be
appropriated for its use by the Board of Aldermen.
   (e)   The Commission may recommend to the Board of Aldermen suitable
arrangements for the procurement or provision of staff or technical services
for the Commission.
(Ord. of 1/26/93)
Section 2-7078 through 2-7080 reserved.
ARTICLE F
Camp Hope Commission
Section 2-7081 Authority.
   This article is enacted pursuant to authority conveyed by G.S. 160A-146.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7082 Establishment and composition.
   There is hereby created an advisory commission to be known as the Town of
Canton Camp Hope Commission, which shall consist of nine members appointed by
the Board of Aldermen/women. In addition to the nine members, the Commission
shall have two non-voting ex-officio members, selected from the Board of
Aldermen/women.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7083 Qualifications of members.
   (a)   Five members are required to reside inside the corporate Town limits.
Up to four members may reside outside of the corporate Town limits.
   (b)   Where possible, appointments to the Commission shall be made in such a
manner as to maintain at all times a majority of members who have had special
training or experience in ground or facility maintenance, outdoor recreation,
forestry, architecture, landscape architecture, planning, or business
administration.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7084 Terms of members.
   (a)   Members shall serve for a term of two years and until their successors
are appointed and qualified, except for the term of the member who represents
the Board which shall automatically terminate at any time his/her affiliation
with such unit ends. Members may serve up to three consecutive terms and must
wait one term cycle before reappointment.
   (b)   Vacancies occurring for reasons other than the expiration of terms
shall be filled by the Board of Aldermen/women as they occur for the period of
the unexpired term.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7085 Compensation of members.
   Members of the Commission shall serve without pay, but may be reimbursed for
actual expenses incidental to the performance of their duties, within the
limits of funds available to the Commission. In all cases, any such
reimbursement shall only be made in accordance with policies approved by the
Board of Aldermen/women.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7086 Advisory function.
   The Commission shall serve in an advisory capacity to the Town Board of
Aldermen/women and the Town Manager on matters pertaining to or affecting the
maintenance, operation, and long range planning of Camp Hope.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7087 Organization, rules, meetings, and records.
   (a)   Within 30 days after its appointment, the Commission shall meet and
elect a Chair and Vice Chair and such other officers as it may deem necessary
for the orderly conduct of its business. The term of the Chair and other
officers shall be one year with eligibility for re-election.
   (b)   The Commission shall hold regular meetings at such times and places as
it may designate. The Commission shall hold at least six meetings per year. The
Commission’s meetings shall be open to the public and the Commission shall
comply with the Open Meetings Law.
   (c)   The Commission shall adopt bylaws, rules and regulations covering its
procedure not inconsistent with the provisions of this Code and applicable
State laws.
   (d)   The Commission shall adopt rules to govern the conduct of its meetings
based upon Robert’s Rules of Order.
   (e)   The Commission shall keep a record of its members’ attendance and of
its resolutions, discussions, findings and recommendations. A copy of the
minutes of each meeting shall be filed with the Clerk. The minutes and other
official documents of the Commission shall be public records.
   (f)   For the purpose of taking any official action authorized or required,
there shall be present a quorum of five members.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7088 Change; modification of powers.
   The powers and authority granted by this article to the Camp Hope Commission
may be changed, altered, modified or amended by the Board at any time at its
discretion.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7089 Purposes and powers.
   It shall be the purpose of the Commission to advise the Board of Aldermen/
women and the Town Manager on the maintenance, operation, and long range
planning of Camp Hope in order to support its preservation for public use in
perpetuity. To that end, the Commission shall have the following powers:
   (a)   Formulate ideas and concepts for new programming and present
recommendations to the Board of Aldermen/women and Town Manager for approval;
   (b)   Promote and assist in the implementation of new programs as approved
by the Board of Aldermen/women and Town Manager;
   (c)   Assist staff with the planning and execution of volunteer projects in
accordance to the Town’s risk management policies;
   (d)   Plan and conduct Commission-led maintenance projects that
appropriately align with the skill levels of members in coordination with the
Town;
   (e)   Plan and execute fundraising activities for capital improvements in
conjunction with Town staff;
   (f)   Assist staff with evaluating building and grounds conditions and
prioritizing deferred maintenance projects based on health, safety, and
welfare;
   (g)   Foster the communication and coordination among citizens of the Town,
the community surrounding Camp Hope, and the region in order to increase public
awareness of Camp Hope and bring about support for Camp Hope initiatives;
   (h)   Conduct research on the management and planning of public campgrounds,
wilderness areas, and outdoor event venues;
   (i)   Assist staff with the development of rental policies and fee
structures;
   (j)   Conduct public meetings and hearings as needed;
   (k)   Research various grant sources to support capital improvements; and
   (l)   Ensure the Town is operating the facility in accordance to all
enumerated deed restrictions.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)
Section 2-7090 Annual reporting, purchasing, cash handling, and fundraising.
   (a)   The Board of Aldermen/women may appropriate such funds as it deems
necessary and available to support improvements and operations for Camp Hope.
Such funds shall be administered by staff under the advisement of the
Commission.
   (b)   The Commission shall, no later than April 15 of each year, submit in
writing to the Town Manager and Board of Aldermen/women a written report of its
activities for the fiscal year.
   (c)   The Commission shall have no authority to incur any financial
obligation or liability in the name of the Town. Only Town staff, following
State purchasing laws and Town purchasing policies, may enter into contacts or
purchase orders for Camp expenditures. Whenever possible, staff shall make
supplies and material purchases for the Camp. Commission members may make
purchases for materials and supplies from time to time to an open vendor
account upon written approval of Town staff.
   (d)   The Town shall collect all fees for rentals.
   (e)   The Commission is authorized to contact and network with private
agencies, foundations, organizations, individuals, and the State or the Federal
government to discuss funding opportunities.
   (f)   All formal requests for grant funding shall be made through the Town
as the applicant upon approval from the Board of Aldermen/women.
   (g)   The Commission is authorized to solicit donations directly from
private individuals with the understanding that all such donations shall be
coordinated with Town staff for collection according to proper accounting
procedures prescribed by the Town.
   (h)   The Commission may recommend to the Board of Aldermen/women suitable
arrangements for the procurement or provision of staff or technical services
for the Commission.
   (i)   All fundraising activities shall be coordinated with staff and all
collections shall be handled in strict accordance to Town cash handling
policies.
(Ord. of 7/24/14)

ARTICLE A
Police Department
Section 3-1001 Organization.
   The police department of the Town shall consist of a chief and as many
policemen as the Manager, under the general direction of the Board, shall from
time to time determine, and as many special policemen as may be necessary to
appoint for special purposes.
Section 3-1002 Manager to have control.
   The Manager shall have general supervision over the police department. The
Manager may suspend any member of the police department until the next regular
meeting at which time final disposition of the matter giving rise to the
suspension shall be made.
Section 3-1003 Chief of police.
   Public Safety The chief shall have control over the police department under
the supervision of the Manager. The chief shall keep the Manager informed of
the department's activities and make such reports that the Manager may from
time to time require, and he shall perform such other duties as may be required
of him by the Manager. The chief of police shall reside within the corporate
limits of the Town of Canton.
(Amended by Ord. of 9/24/85)
Section 3-1004 Uniforms.
   All police officers shall wear uniforms as shall be provided by the Town,
shall keep such uniforms in a neat and clean condition and shall surrender all
uniforms and equipment upon leaving the police service of the Town if such
uniforms and equipment were furnished by the Town.
Section 3-1005 Powers and duties of policemen.
   Each policeman shall:
      (1)   Have within the corporate limits of the Town all of the powers
invested in law-enforcement officers by statute or common law;
      (2)   Have power to serve all civil and criminal process that may be
directed to him by any officer of the General Court of Justice;
      (3)   Rigidly enforce all laws, ordinances and regulations of the Town
and the State of North Carolina and report each and every violation thereof to
the Mayor; and
      (4)   At all times preserve the peace and protect the property and the
safety of the citizens of the Town.
Section 3-1006 Resisting police prohibited.
   No person shall resist the police while. in the discharge of their duty, by
force, words or threats, or any attempt to excite others to resistance, or in
any other manner obstruct them in the performance of their duty.
Editorial Note: For additional provisions regarding the polio department see
G.S. 160A-281; 160A-285.
Section 3-1007 through 3-1010 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Auxiliary Police
Section 3-1011 Auxiliary police division established.
   There is hereby established within the Town police department, as a division
thereof, an auxiliary police division. The auxiliary police division shall be a
volunteer organization, composed of as many members as may from time to time be
determined by the Manager.
Section 3-1012 Chief of police to control; appointments and removals.
   (a)   The auxiliary police division shall be under the direct control of the
chief of police, acting under the general supervision of the Manager. All
appointments and removals of members of the auxiliary police division shall be
made in the same manner and under the same policies and procedures as may from
time to time be established for appointment and removal of regular police
officers.
   (b)   The auxiliary police division shall have no commanding officer, nor
any officers, and all members shall bear the rank of patrolman. Each member of
the auxiliary police division shall take the oath of office of a regular
policeman. The chief of police shall provide for adequate training of members
of the auxiliary police division, and of candidates for membership.
Section 3-1013 Duties.
   (a)   The duties of the auxiliary police division, subject at all times to
the direction, supervision and control of the chief of police, shall be 'to
assist the regular members of the police department in the enforcement of law
and the maintenance of peace and order when called to active duty by the chief
of police. The chief shall by order establish rules and regulations to govern
the auxiliary police division, to fix the specific duties of its members, and
to provide for the maintenance of discipline. Members of the auxiliary police
division shall obey the instructions of regular police officers in carrying out
their duties.
   (b)   The chief may prescribe other duties than those mentioned herein to be
performed by the auxiliary police division, with approval of the Manager.
Section 3-1014 Identification.
   An identification card and such other insignia or evidence of identity as
the chief may prescribe shall be issued to each member of the auxiliary police
division who must carry the card and other identification at all times while on
duty, and who must surrender them upon the termination of his membership.
Section 3-1015 Carrying and custody of firearms.
   Members of the auxiliary police division may, while on duty, carry or use
any firearm upon order of the chief of police.
Editorial Note: For provisions at to the authority of a municipality to create
auxiliary police positions see G.S. 160A-282.

Section
3-2021   Description.
ARTICLE A
Fire Department
Section 3-2001 Organization.
   The fire department shall consist of the chief of the fire department and a
sufficient number of firemen (voluntary, part or full time) to maintain and
operate the department. The Manager shall appoint the chief and approve the
appointment to the department of all members. The department may from time to
time adopt its own rules and regulations governing the department subject to
the approval of the Manager and the Board. However, any such rules and
regulations shall include provisions for at least one training period each
month and that any member who is absent from two consecutive meetings without a
bona fide reason be dropped from the department.
Section 3-2002 Duties of chief.
   (1)   Have general control of the department, the personnel, apparatus, and
fire alarm systems.
   (2)   Command the department and supervise the fire-fighting and
extinguishing of all fires and shall have the authority to keep away from the
vicinity of all fires, any and all idle, disorderly or suspicious persons.
   (3)   Inspect or cause to be inspected all trucks and other equipment of the
fire department each and every week to ascertain that such equipment is being
kept in proper condition. He shall report annually to the Manager the condition
of all equipment.
   (4)   Inspect or cause to be inspected all fire hydrants and fire alarm
systems at least once every three months and shall make a report of such
inspection to the Manager.
   (3)   The fire department chief shall reside within the corporate limits of
the Town of Canton. (Amended by Ord. of 9/24/85)
State Law Reference: Duties of fire chief enumerated, G.S. 160A-292.
Section 3-2003 Same; duties as fire inspector.
   (a)   The chief is to assume the functions of fire inspector. As such, he
(or his designated agent) shall have authority to enter any and all premises,
at a reasonable time, for purposes of inspection.
   (b)   Routine inspections. He shall make annual inspections of all
structures located within the fire district.
   (c)   Inspections upon 'complaint. He shall, upon receipt of a complaint
forthwith investigate.
   (d)   He shall investigate the causes of fires and shall keep records of his
findings as to origin, location, owner, extent of damage and injury, and amount
of insurance carried. The findings must be reported to the North Carolina
Insurance Commissioner at regular intervals.
   (e)   He shall cause the removal of fire hazards by serving proper orders to
the owner or agent of premises in question, such orders to state a reasonable
time limit. Failure to comply with such order shall be considered a
misdemeanor.
Section 3-2004 General authority at fires.
   (a)   The officer in command shall have authority to summon aid and no
citizen so summoned may refuse to help in extinguishing the fire or n
protecting exposed property.
   (b)   During the continuance of a fire, the fire chief, his assistant or the
Mayor shall have authority to call upon any citizen to render assistance in
pulling down or demolishing any building or in removing goods or furniture from
a building on fire or in danger of fire, but not without the consent of the
officer of the fire department or the police department who may be in charge.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful to congregate on the streets or alleys near a
fire in a manner which would interfere with the activities of the fire
department.
   (d)   In the event of an alarm of fire the apparatus of the fire department
responding to it shall have the right-of-way in and upon all streets, lanes,
alleys and other public ways.
   (e)   The drivers of vehicles, upon the approach of fire' apparatus shall
immediately bring their vehicle to a stop on the right hand side of the street
in the direction in which they are facing and shall not move their vehicle
until such apparatus has passed.
Section 3-2005 Interfering With firemen or fire apparatus.
   No person shall interfere with a fireman in the discharge of his duty, or
hinder him in the performance of said duty; nor shall any person other than
members of the fire department loiter about any fire station, or change,
handle, or meddle in any manner with any fire engine or any other fire
apparatus.
Section 3-2006 Only firemen may ride on trucks without permission.
No person other than a bona fide member of the fire department shall mount any
fire engine, wagon or apparatus before it leaves the station or while on its
way to or from a fire, or at any other time, unless by permission of the driver
or officer in command of such engine, wagon or apparatus.
State Law Reference: Interference with fire equipment; following emergency
vehicles; running over fire hose,. G.S. 20-157.
Section 3-2007 Interfering with fire alarm apparatus.
   No person shall interfere carelessly or willfully with the fire alarm system
or injure the poles, wires, boxes, or other apparatus connected therewith.
Section 3-2008 Fire protection outside of Town.
   In the event that the Town agrees with the county, or the owners of property
outside the Town, to provide fire protection therefor, any employee of the fire
department, while engaged in any duty or activity outside the corporate limits
of the Town pursuant to orders of the fire chief or Manager, shall have all of
the jurisdiction, authority, rights, privileges, and immunities, including
coverage under the workmen's compensation laws, which they have within the
corporate limits of the Town.
State Law Reference: Fire protection outside city limits; maintenance of
equipment; jurisdiction, G.S. 160A-293.
Section 3-2009 Technical codes and standards adopted by reference.
   (a)   There is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein the
current edition of the North Carolina State Building Code: Fire Prevention
Code. Copies of this Fire Prevention Ordinance of the Town of Canton and all
technical codes and standards are available for public inspection in the office
of the Fire Chief.
   (b)   Amendments to codes and standards adopted by reference herein which
are adopted and published by the North Carolina State Building Code Council
shall be effective in the Town of Canton at the time such amendments become a
part of North Carolina State Building Code: Fire Prevention Code. (Ord. of 3/
28/24)
Section 3-2010 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Fire Prevention and Hazards
Section 3-2011 Open fires prohibited in fire limits.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite, use or maintain any open or
unenclosed fire within the fire limits of the Town.
(Code 1963, Sec. 8-1)
Section 3-2012 Use of tar pots in fire, limits.
   Any person using a tar pot for heating tar within the fire limits of the
Town shall use a type of pot which is enclosed in such a manner that the fire
cannot come in contact with the tar, and it shall be unlawful for any person to
use an open tar pot for heating tar within the fire limits of the Town.
(Code 1963, Sec. 8-2)
Section 3-2013 Smoking in theaters or meeting halls.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke any cigarette, cigar, pipe or
other article, or strike any match, lighter, or other Inflammable or explosive,
in any moving picture show or theater in the Town while a show is in progress,
or in any other public gathering held in an enclosed structure. This section
shall apply from the time the door is opened for admission until the last
person has been cleared from the entire structure.
(Code 1963, Sec. 8-3)
Section 3-2014 Interference with firemen; approaching site of fire.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder or interfere with any fireman
at the scene of a fire, and no person except duly qualified firemen, shall
approach nearer than 100 feet to the site of a fire, without permission from
the fire chief.
(Code 1963, Sec. 8-4)
Cross Reference: Interference with fire apparatus, Sec.
3-2005.
Section 3-2015 through 3 2020 reserved.
ARTICLE C
Fire Limits
Section 3-2021 Description.
   The area embraced in the description herein set forth is hereby established
and designated as the primary fire limits in the Town of Canton:
   Beginning at a point in the center of the Main line of Southern Railway and
the south margin of Old Clyde Road, where Old Clyde Road crosses said railroad,
and runs thence with the south margin of Old Clyde Road a westerly direction to
Canton corporate limits; thence with the Canton corporate limits a southerly
course crossing U.S. 19-23 to a point 150 feet south of the south margin of
U.S. 19-23; thence parallel with U.S. 19-23 and 150 feet from the south margin
of said highway an east course to a point 150 feet south from the south margin
of the connection of U.S. 19-23 and Park Street; thence continuing parallel
with Park Street and 150 feet from the south margin of Park Street an east
course to a point 150 feet south from the south margin of the intersection of
Park Street and Main Street; thence continuing parallel with Main Street and
150 feet from the south margin of Main Street an east course to a point 150
feet south from the south margin of the intersection of Main Street and Church
Street; thence parallel with Church Street and 150 feet from the south margin
of Church Street a northeasterly course to a point measured at right angle from
the intersection of Church and Bridge Streets; thence parallel with Bridge
Street and 150 feet from the east margin of said Bridge Street a north course
to the center of the Main line of the Southern Railway; thence with the center
of said Main line of Southern Railway a westerly course to the beginning.
State Law Reference: Board required to establish fire limits, G.S. 160A-435.
Restrictions within fire limits, G.S. 160A-436.

(Reserved)
ARTICLE A
Emergencies
Section 3-3001 State of emergency.
   A state of emergency shall be deemed to exist wherever, during times of
great public crisis, disaster, rioting, catastrophe, or similar public
emergency, for any reason, municipal public safety authorities are unable to
maintain public order or afford adequate protection for lives, safety or
property.
(Code 1963, Sec. 6A-1)
State Law Reference: Powers of the mayor during state of emergency, G.S. 14-
288.12.
Section 3-3002 Proclamation of state of emergency.
   In the event of an existing or threatened state of emergency endangering the
lives, safety, health and welfare of the people within the Town or threatening
damage to or destruction of property, the Mayor is hereby authorized and
empowered to issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the existence
of such a state of emergency, and, in order more effectively to protect the
lives, safety and property of people within the Town, to define and impose a
curfew applicable to all persons within the jurisdiction of the Town.
(Code 1963, Sec. 6A-3)
Section 3-3003 Curfew.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to limit the application of
such a curfew to any area specifically designated and described within the
corporate limits of the Town and to specific hours of the day or night; and to
exempt from the curfew policemen, firemen, doctors, nurses, and such other
classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and
immediately necessary to serve the safety, health and welfare needs of the
people within the Town.
(Code 1963, Sec. 6A-4)
Section 3-3004 Termination of curfew and state of emergency.
   The Mayor shall proclaim the end of such state and curfew as soon as
circumstances warrant or when directed to do so by the Board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 6A-5)
Section 3-3005 Unlawful activities during state of emergency.
   During the existence of a proclaimed state of emergency when a curfew has
been imposed, it shall be unlawful for anyone subject to such curfew:
   (1)   To be or travel upon any public street, alley, or roadway or upon
public property, unless in search of medical assistance, food, or other
commodity or service necessary to sustain the well-being of himself or his
family or some member thereof.
   (2)   To possess off one's own premises, buy, sell, give away, or otherwise
transfer or dispose of any explosives, firearms, ammunition, or dangerous
weapon of any kind.
   (3)   To sell beer, wines, or intoxicating beverages of any kind; or to
possess or consume the same off one's own premises.
   (4)   To sell gasoline or any other similar petroleum products, or any other
inflammable substances, except as expressly authorized by the provisions of the
curfew imposed.
(Code 1963, Sec. 6A-6)
Section 3-3006 Penalty for violation of article.
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor, punishable upon conviction by a fine not exceeding $50.00 or
imprisonment not exceeding 30 days as provided by G. S. 14-4.
(Code 1963, Sec. 6A-2)

Civil Defense Department
Section 3-3007 through 3-3010 reserved.

ARTICLE A
Acceptance and Improvement of Public Streets
Section 4-1001 Definitions.
   For the purposes of this article, the following definitions and rules of
construction shall apply to the words and phrases used herein:
   Front footage. "Front footage" shall be determined to be that portion of the
perimeter of the property owner's property which abuts on the right-of-way or
easement where the public improvement is installed.
   Petition. The word "petition" shall mean any written document wherein is
contained a request from a property owner for public improvements.
   Public improvement. The term "public improvement" shall mean any water,
sewer, street, sidewalk, or storm drainage installation of a new construction
nature.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7- 1)
   Cross Reference: Charter provisions on street improvements, Charter, Section
4-1 et seq. Street and sidewalk use and regulation, section
6-2001 et seq. Excavation and repair, section
6-1011 et seq.
Section 4-1002 Petition generally.
   Before any public improvement is begun, a petition shall be submitted to the
Town Manager for presentation to the Board. The petition shall be submitted on
a form furnished by the Town and it shall be signed by both husband and wife.
Such petition shall contain the following information: Location of the
improvement as accurately as possible; nature and size of the improvement;
statement that property owners are willing to pay the assessment cost as
prescribed in this article; and signatures of property owners involved,
together with the exact front footage which each owns. The sufficiency of any
petition will be judged by the requirements of this article.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7-2)
Section 4-1003 Rights-of-way or easements required.
   No public improvement shall be constructed by the town except upon public
rights-of-way or easements dedicated to the Town. Such rights-of-way or
easements shall be required to be furnished to the Town at no expense to the
Town.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7-3)
Section 4-1004 Cost sharing by Town and property owners.
   It shall be the policy of the Town to participate in the cost of any public
improvement to the extent of one-third (1/3) of the total cost of any project.
The remaining two-thirds (2/3) of such cost shall be shared equally by the
property owners abutting on the improvement on a pro rata basis based upon
front footage of the property owner's respective lot.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7-4)
Section 4-1005 Assessments.
   (a)   Payment. Property owners shall be required to pay assessments for
public improvements at a rate of one-fifth ( 1/5) for year starting 30 days
from the date of the adoption of the assessment roll, except that a property
owner may pay the unpaid balance at any time he desires.
   (b)   Interest on deferred assessments. Deferred assessments shall bear
interest at the rate of six per cent (6%) for annum on the unpaid balance
beginning 30 days from the date of adoption of the assessment roll.
   (c)   Recurrence. It shall be the policy of the Town to assess for a public
improvement one time only in any given location. All cost of maintenance and
replacement shall thereafter be borne by the Town.
   (d)   Relief. The Board shall have power to relieve assessments where use of
the improvement is forever impossible by the property owner.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7-5)
Cross Reference: Public improvement assessments generally, section
4-1 et seq. of Charter. Adjustment, release or remission of assessments.
Related Local Laws, page L-1.
Section 4-1006 Adoption of resolution contrary to article.
   The Mayor and Board of Aldermen may, upon unanimous vote of all members
present, adopt a resolution contrary to this article which finds as a fact that
the public necessity of the whole population of tho Town or the purposes of the
Town government would be unduly hampered by the strict enforcement of this
article. Upon the adoption of such a resolution, the Board may order such
public improvements as may be required for the public convenience and in such
manner as the Board may prescribe. The following shall be examples, but not
exclusive. of the types of construction which this section permits: Outfall
sewer lines to a treatment plant; water mains to serve the entire population of
the Town; major thoroughfares and traffic loops.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7-6)
Section 4-1007 Street improvements.
   (a)   Sufficiency of petition. A petition for street improvements shall be
deemed sufficient when the petition contains the signatures of the owners of
fifty-one per cent (51%) of the total front footage abutting on the proposed
improvement.
   (b)   Minimum right-of-way. No street improvements shall be made on any
right-of-way less than 30 feet in width, except those owned by the Town on May
10. 1960.
   (c)   Prerequisites to acceptance of street. No street shall be accepted by
the Town unless the same has been opened, graded properly, graveled, and a
petition obtained for the paving, curbing and guttering thereof. Such street
shall also have a right-of-way of not less than 30 feet in width.
   (d)   Town to bear entire cost of excess street widths. It shall be the
policy of the Town to bear the entire cost of a street improvement for all
street widths in excess of 30 feet. It is the purpose of this subsection to
limit the property owner's responsibility to that width which serves as a
residential street. with the Town bearing the cost of excess street widths
which constitute major thoroughfares.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7-16)
Section 4-1008 Sidewalk improvement.
   (a)   Sufficiency of petition. A petition for sidewalk improvements shall be
deemed sufficient when it shall contain the signatures of the owners of fifty-
one per cent (51%) of the property abutting directly on the proposed
improvement.
   (b)   Width. The sidewalk width shall be such as may be agreed upon by the
property owners involved and the Board.
(Code 1963, Sec. 7-17)
   Cross Reference: Charter provisions on street improvements, Charter, section
4-1 et seq. Street and sidewalk use and regulation, section
6-2001 et seq. Excavation and repair, section
6-1001 et seq. Sewer improvements, section
5-1001 et seq.
Section 4-1009 through 4-1020 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Excavation and Repair
Section 4-1021 Permit to dig in streets.
   No person shall make any excavation or opening or dig any ditch, trench,
tunnel or hole in, along, across or under any street, sidewalk or other public
place for the purpose of laying or placing therein any pipe, wires, poles or
for any other purposes, unless a written permit therefor has been issued by the
Town manager or some other officer of the Town vested with authority to grant
the same. Provided, that a permit shall not be required where such work is
performed under a contract with the Town but in the event that It becomes
necessary to such work that a sidewalk or street must be wholly or partially
obstructed, the person shall notify the manager, the public works department
and the police department at least two hours before obstructing the sidewalk or
street, unless prevented by sudden emergency.
(Code 1963, Sec. 15 21)
Section 4-1022 Application for permit; fees.
   All persons desiring a permit in order to make an opening in any street or
sidewalk, as set forth in section 41021, shall make written application
therefor, which application shall show the location of the proposed opening,
the purpose thereof and the approximate number of square yards of surface to be
cut. Such application shall be accompanied by a fee. The fee required for
making any opening in any street or sidewalk shall be as established by the
Board and maintained on file in the office of the Town Clerk.
Section 4-1023 Indemnity agreement required of applicant; Town's liability.
   Any person obtaining a permit as provided for in sections 41021 and 41022
herein agrees, as a condition of the issuance of said permit to indemnify and
hold harmless the Town against any claims or expenses, including attorney's
fees for bodily injury or property damage for accidents or occurrences arising
out of the person's operations, excluding only the liability of the Town for
its sole negligence except in connection with general supervision of work
performed by said person.
(Code 1963, Sec. 15-23)
Section 4-1024 Refilling of excavations, etc., required; failure to comply with
section.
   When any part of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place of the
Town shall be torn or dug up for any purpose, the person making such excavation
or opening shall have the duty of refilling such excavation or opening so as to
restore it to essentially the same condition that existed prior to the
excavation or opening and such refilling shall be done in accordance with the
standards and specifications issued by the director of public works or his duly
authorized representative. Any person, firm or corporation, neglecting,
refusing, or failing to comply with any provisions of this section shall be
guilty of a violation thereof; and where such neglect, refusal or failure is
continued, after notice from the said director of public works or his
authorized representative, every day's continuance thereafter shall constitute
a separate and distinct offense.
(Code 1963, Sec. 10-24)
Section 4-1025 Guard rails, signal lights, etc., at excavations.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation who obtain a permit
under the sections of this article to do any excavation of any kind which may
create or cause a dangerous condition in or near any street, alley, sidewalk or
public place of the Town without placing and maintaining proper guard rails and
signal lights or other warnings at, in or around the same, sufficient to warn
the public of such excavation or work, and to protect all persons using
reasonable care from injuries on account of the same.
(Code 1963, Sec. 10-25)
Section 4-1026 Supervision and inspection of work.
   All excavations and work in streets, sidewalks, alleys or public places of
the Town shall be under the supervision and control of the director of public
works, or an individual appointed by the Manager, whose duty it shall be to
inspect the same from time to time during the progress thereof. Upon the
completion thereof, he shall make a final inspection and see that the street,
sidewalk or public place is restored to a condition as good in all respects as
before the excavation or work was made or done, and that all debris, materials,
tools and equipment are removed therefrom. Any person refusing or failing to
comply with any provision of this section shall be guilty of a violation
thereof; and where such failure or refusal is continued after notice from the
director of public works or designated official, every day's continuance shall
constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(Code 1963, Sec. 15-26)
Section 4-1027 Fees to be paid into general fund.
   All fees collected under the provisions of this article shall be paid into
the general fund.
(Code 1963, Sec. 15-27)
Section 4-1028 Penalty for violation.
   All persons found guilty of violation of this article shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than S 50.00 or imprisoned for not more
than 30 days.
(Code 1963, Sec. 15-29)
Section 4-1029 through 41030 reserved.

Street Naming

CHAPTER 2
Garbage and Refuse Collection and Disposal
Section
4-2001   Definitions.
Section
4-2002   Receptacles required.
Section
4-2003   Construction of receptacles; covers; handles.

4-2004   Maximum capacity of receptacle.
Section
4-2005   Location and maintenance.
Section
4-2006   Disposition of defective receptacles.
Section
4-2007   Preparation for collection.
Section
4-2008   Not to be placed so as to interfere with use of street or sidewalk.
Section
