Section
4-2010   Tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery; leaves; removal of tree stumps.
Section
4-2011   Discarded appliances and similar objects.
Cross-reference: Accumulation constituting a nuisance, see Section
8-6015.
Section 4-2001 Definitions.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them:
   Combustible waste. Includes yard trimmings, rags, waste wood, cardboard, and
other combustible waste solids of a nonvolatile or nonexplosive nature.
   Garbage. Any animal or vegetable waste solids resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooling or consumption of foods.
   Noncombustible waste. All solid waste material which does not burn.
   Refuse. Garbage and combustible and noncombustible waste solids.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-1)
Section 4-2002 Receptacles required.
   (a)   The owner, agent, lessee, tenant or occupant of every dwelling or
other premises where refuse accumulates shall provide and keep on such premises
receptacles for receiving and holding refuse. At least one such receptacle
shall be provided for each family unit or other occupant of the premises.
   (b)   Any business establishment or person which requires the use of a
dumpster of two to six yards, must furnish their own dumpster and said dumpster
must meet the specifications of the sanitation truck used by the Town. A copy
of the specifications will be on file in the Clerk's Office in the Municipal
Building.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-2) (Amended by Ord. of 6/30/92)
Section 4-2003 Construction of receptacles; covers, handles.
   Each receptacle required by Section
4-2002 shall be constructed of metal or plastic and so constructed as to
prevent spilling or leakage of its contents. Each such receptacle shall be
watertight and shall be equipped with a tight-fitting cover which shall be kept
in place at all times when the receptacle is not being filled or emptied. Each
such receptacle shall also be equipped with a pull handle or handles.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-3)
Section 4-2004 Maximum capacity of receptacle.
   Each receptacle required by Section
4-2002(a) shall have a capacity of not more than 30 gallons each. Dumpsters
required by Section
4-2002(b) shall have a capacity of two yards to six yards.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-4) (Amended by Ord. of 6/30/92)
Section 4-2005 Location and maintenance.
   (a)   Receptacles required by Section
4-2002(a) shall be located on the premises at least 20 feet back from the
street curb on the front and 20 feet back from the side boundaries, for storage
of refuse, and maintained in such manner as to prevent the creation of a
nuisance or menace to public health.
   (b)   Dumpsters required by Section
4-2002(b) shall be located at a convenient and accessible place.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-5) (Amended by Ord. of 1/14/86; Ord. of 6/30/92)
Section 4-2006 Disposition of defective receptacles.
   Refuse receptacles which are badly broken or otherwise fail to meet the
requirements of this chapter may be classed as refuse and collected and
disposed of as such by the person or agency responsible for the collection of
refuse.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-6)
Section 4-2007 Preparation for collection.
   Refuse accumulated or produced in the Town and to be collected by the Town
shall be prepared as follows:
   (1)   Garbage. Garbage shall be thoroughly and completely drained of all
liquids, wrapped securely in paper and placed in a receptacle meeting the
requirements of this chapter.
   (2)   Paper. Paper shall be securely and properly tied into bundles or other
packages in such manner as to prevent any scattering while awaiting or during
collection. The bundles or packages shall be of a size and weight to permit
ease of handling by one man.
   (3)   Waste not deposited in receptacles. Combustible or noncombustible
waste of such a nature that it cannot be deposited in a receptacle required by
this chapter shall be securely and properly tied into bundles or packages to
prevent spilling or scattering and placed in an accessible place near the
sidewalk or street. The bundles or packages or other containers shall be of a
size and weight to permit ease of handling by one man, or shall be assembled in
quantities weighing not more than 50 pounds.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-7)
Section 4-2008 Not to be placed so as to interfere with use of street or
sidewalk.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to put or place, or allow or permit to
be put or placed, any refuse on the street or sidewalk or near enough there to
that it will interfere with the free use of and passage on the street or
sidewalk.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-8)
   Cross Reference: Street and sidewalk obstructions generally, section
6-2001 et seq.
Section 4-2009 Frequency of removal and removal charges.
   (a)   Garbage and refuse shall be removed from business and residential
property by the Town forces at such intervals and on such schedules as may be
fixed from time to time by the Board. The charges to be collected by the Town
for garbage and refuse removal service shall be such as prescribed by the Board
from time to time.
(Code 1963, Sec. 9-9)
   (b)   In accordance with the provisions of G.S. 160A-314, fees incurred by
the Town for the disposal of any solid waste shall be charged to the water/
sewer/garbage account of the customer ordering the disposal. Disposal fees
shall be listed separately from the other services. Failure to pay for the
disposal fees shall be treated in accordance with the uniform policy for
nonpayment of water and sewer bills.
(Ord. of 7/9/02)
   State Law Reference: Authority of Town to regulate removal of trash and
garbage and to make charges therefor, G.S. 160A-192.
Section 4-2010   Tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery; leaves; removal of tree
stumps.
   (a)   The Town will attempt to collect tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery, and
the like from each residence of the Town on an as needed as called basis;
however, during leaf season, this service will likely be curtailed to allow the
collection of leaves. This service shall be limited to the amount of tree
limbs, cuttings, shrubbery, and the like that a typical resident shall produce
in normal yard work and is not a service provided to a landscaping firm or to a
private tree company or to individuals who are paid to trim trees, redo
landscaping or perform major yard work. Such debris produced by these firms
shall not be collected by the Town, and the property owner or tenant shall be
responsible for the cost of removal and disposal of such material. Volumes of
more than one truckload or volumes which will take more than 30 minutes to load
will not be collected without a charge to the customer. Excess volumes or time
shall be billed at the rates prescribed and changed from time to time by the
Board of Aldermen and kept on file at the Town Clerk's office. In any case,
such limbs, cuttings, shrubbery and the like shall not be greater than six feet
in length, nor more than three inches in diameter nor of such a weight that it
may not be handled by one person. This debris is to be placed along the edge of
the owner's or tenant's property nearest the street right-of-way, with cut ends
facing the street, and shall not block any sidewalk or be in the street where
vehicles might be prohibited from safe passage. Tree limbs and yard trimmings
shall be free of trash, dirt, wire or anything that could damage chipping
equipment. Lawn trimmings shall be placed in boxes, cans or bags for pickup and
the weight of a single container device shall not exceed 30 pounds. Machine
piled material, logs and/or stumps shall not be collected. Material addressed
in this section shall not be placed in the street or in gutters or drainage
ways so as to inhibit storm drainage or so that the material might wash into or
block catch basins.
   (b)   The Town shall at no time remove or assist in the removal of stumps
resulting from the clearing of property of any kind.
   (c)   In situations where there is danger for Town employees or concern for
the safety of the motoring public, the street superintendent, at his or her
discretion, may authorize the collection of any permitted materials from a
point off the street rights-of-way and out of the path of vehicular traffic.
(Ord. of 9/27/05)
Section 4-2011   Discarded appliances and similar objects.
   It shall be the duty of the property owner who wishes to dispose of
discarded appliances such as water heaters, stoves, electronic appliances and
any other items too large to be hauled by a regular garbage truck to call the
street/sanitation department and request a special pickup. This is a service
provided to residential customers in the normal replacement of home appliances,
and shall not be provided to establishments which are in the business of
selling and allowing trade-ins of such appliances.
(Ord. of 9/27/05)

CHAPTER 4
Sanitary Landfill
Section
4-4001   Restriction to waste originating in County.
Section
4-4002   Fees for solid waste disposal.
Section

Section
4-4004   Capital Reserve Fund.
Section 4-4001   Restriction to waste originating in County.
   The Town sanitary landfill is restricted to non-hazardous solid waste
originating in Haywood County. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge
waste which originated outside the County in the Town landfill.
(Ord. of 8/12/86; as amended by Ord. of 8/26/86)
Section 4-4002   Fees for solid waste disposal.
   (a)     User fees are charged for the disposal of solid waste at the Town's
landfill.
   (b)    The fee for disposal at said facilities shall be at the following
rates:
   (1)   $23 per ton of solid waste;
   (2)   Minimum rate to be $2 for automobiles and station wagons;
   (3)   Minimum rate to be $4 for pickup trucks;
   (4)   Champion International is to be excepted from these rates; and
   (5)   These rates may be changed from time to time by the Mayor and the
Board of Aldermen without the adoption of an ordinance.
   (c)    Businesses and commercial carriers hauling regular loads daily would
be required to fill out an application at the Town Hall in order to be billed
for
landfill use; all others would be cash only at the time of dumping waste.
Short-term contract haulers shall make a $100 deposit.
   (d)   Residential customers living within the Town limits and having solid
waste originating inside the Town limits may obtain a pass to deposit debris in
the landfill free of charge.
(Ord. of 8/25/87; as amended by Ord. of 6/26/90; as amended by Ord. of 7/29/92)
Section 4-4003   Town landfill to accept tires on fee basis.
   The Town landfill will accept tires beginning April 1, 1989, according to
the fee schedule below:
$1.00 per tire -   Car and light truck tires: Highway car/truck tires, under 20
inches in diameter. You unload in designated area.
$2.00 per tire -   Truck tires: 20 inches and over, 10.0020 to 1124.5, you
unload in designated area.
$9.00 per tire -   Larger tires: Duplex tires (double width), tractor tires (12
ply or less), you unload in designated area.
Tires not accepted: Tires 4 feet in diameter and over (quote basis only). No
shredded tires (at this time). No foam filled tires. No solid tires (forklift).
No laminated tires.
Section 4-4004 Capital Reserve Fund.
   (a)   The Board of Aldermen hereby creates a Capital Reserve Fund for the
purpose of setting funds aside to be used for major expenditures on landfill
equipment or improvements to the landfill.
   (b)   This Fund will remain operational until the Board considers it
unnecessary or the funds have been disbursed.
   (c)   A portion of landfill fees received will serve as the source of
revenue for the Capital Reserve Fund.
(Ord. of 10/10/89)

ARTICLE A Water System

ARTICLE B Other Provisions
Section
5-1021   Mobile homes.
Section
5-1022   through 5-1030 reserved.
ARTICLE A
Water System
Section 5-1001 Board to regulate water system.
   The water system of the Town shall be under the control of, and the duty of
prescribing and enforcing a full compliance with all the rules and regulations
governing all connections with the public sewer and water system shall be
vested in, the Board or its authorized agent.
Section 5-1002 Permit for connection required.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall connect with the water system of the
Town until they shall have made application for permission to so connect in
writing to the Town Clerk, and this application shall be made before any part
of the drainage system of the house or other connection shall have been laid or
constructed. Such application shall be accompanied with a plan or drawing
showing the location of the building and the entire proposed connection from
the public sewerage line through the building to its terminus, showing the
location of all the fixtures, traps, ventilating pipes, etc., and shall state
the name of the street and the name of the person, firm or corporation.
   Cross Reference: Powers and duties of Board relative to water and sewer
systems, Charter, Section
4-9.
Section 5-1003 Separate connections required.
   Each individual business or residential building or structure shall install
a separate water and sewer connection.
Section 5-1004 Water and sewer required.
   All owners of improved property located within the corporate limits and upon
or within a reasonable distance of any water line owned and operated by the
Town shall connect their premises with the Town water system.
Section 5-1005 Use of Town water.
   (a)   No consumer will be allowed to supply or sell water to other persons,
families or corporations, nor shall any person take or carry away water from
any hydrant, watering trough, or public fountain. This shall not be construed
to prevent the free use of Town water by authorized Town personnel for
municipal purposes.
   (b)   The fire hydrants are for the use of the Fire Department for fighting
fires, and are not to be used by any unauthorized person for any purpose
without permission from the Board.
Section 5-1006 Water rates.
   (a)   Water rates and water connection charges shall be determined from time
to time by the Board and shall be kept on file in the office of the Town Clerk.
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, other than a person authorized
by the Town officials, to turn on the Town supply of water.
   (b)   Any building or structure containing more than one business or one
dwelling unit that does not have a separate water meter for each business or
dwelling unit shall be charged and billed a minimum service fee for each
business or dwelling unit. The charges may be listed on a master bill showing
the cost of the minimums as well as the consumption fee above the minimums.
(Amended by Ord. of 10/23/01)
Section 5-1007 Tampering with or obstructing water lines prohibited.
   No person shall touch, tamper, or in any manner manipulate or turn the
cutoffs on the water mains forming a part of the water system of the Town, nor
shall any person tamper with or harm in any manner whatsoever any water line,
main or any appurtenance thereto. No person shall throw or deposit any material
or substance in any water line that will in any manner obstruct such line.
Section 5-1008 Work on water and sewer system.
   All work on the water system and all connections and disconnections thereto
shall be performed by the authorized employees of the Town or their
representatives or plumbers approved by the Town. All work shall be performed
in accordance with the plumbing code of the State and the Town and such
amendments thereto that the Board may from time to time adopt.
Section 5-1009 Owners of more than one house.
   Any property owner having more than one house using water from the same
watertap shall be responsible for water bills for all the houses.
Section 5-1010 Nonpayment of bills.
   (a)   Under uniform policies established by the Board, service shall be cut
off to premises where bills for water and sewer service are not paid in a
timely manner.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cut the Town water back on when
the same has been cut off by the Town official for the non-payment of any water
bill or account due the Town.
   (c)   When the water that is being used by any person, firm or corporation
has been cut off because of the non-payment of the water account, such person,
firm or corporation shall pay a fee fixed by the Board and kept on file in the
office of the Town Clerk before such water shall be turned back on.
   State Law Reference: Disconnection authorized for nonpayment, G.S. 160A-314.
Section 5-1011 Sewer Extension Policy.
   (a)   Any new service connection to the town's water system outside the
corporate limits shall be subject to the following:
      (1)   Water service to any new customers other than individual single-
family residential uses shall be subject to approval of the Town Planning
Board;
      (2)   Water service to new residential subdivisions shall be considered
only when the subdivision meets the requirements of the Town Subdivision
Ordinance;
      (3)   New water service to lots containing a manufactured home shall be
considered only if the manufactured home meets the appearance criteria
contained in the Manufactured Home Overlay District in the Town Zoning
Ordinance. However, any manufactured home receiving water from the Town as of
the effective date of this policy and not meeting the appearance criteria of
the Town Zoning Ordinance, will not be affected. However, if it is replaced
with another mobile home, it must meet the appearance criteria contained in the
Manufactured Home Overlay District of the Town Zoning Ordinance.
      (4)   No single-wide trailers will receive water and sewer from the Town.
Water associations may establish policies for distribution by their elected
boards concerning mobile homes. New residential subdivisions must meet the
requirements of the Town Subdivision Ordinance.
   (b)   Those portions of the Sewer Extension Policy on file in the Office of
the Mayor and Board of Aldermen not in conflict with existing provisions above
are hereby adopted by reference.
(Ord. of 9/10/96; Amended by Ord. of 3/27/01)
Section 5-1012 Sewer Use Ordinance.
   The Sewer Use Ordinance on file in the Office of the Mayor and Board of
Alderman is hereby adopted by reference.
(Ord. of 3/27/01)
Section 5-1013 Water Conservation Plan.
   The Water Conservation Plan on file in the Office of the Mayor and Board of
Alderman is hereby adopted by reference.
(Ord. of 3/27/01)
Section 5-1014 through 5-1020 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Other Provisions
Section 5-1021 Mobile homes.
   (a)   Mobile home parks (as defined in Part 9, Chapter 4) shall meet all
requirements contained in the Zoning Ordinance for mobile home parks.
   (b)   Mobile homes (as defined in Part 9, Chapter 4) located outside mobile
home parks shall meet the following requirements:
   (1)   Front, side, and rear yard setbacks shall meet the requirements of the
General Residential District Zone as specified in Article VII of the Zoning
Ordinance.
   (2)   When the municipal sewage collection system is not utilized, an
improvements permit must be obtained from the County Health Department,
indicating that the lot on which the mobile home is to be placed is suitable
for use of the proposed sewage treatment system. However, no lot shall be less
than 7,000 square feet.
   (3)   The mobile home shall be underpinned from its bottom to the ground and
for the entire perimeter of the mobile home. The underpinning shall consist of
masonry, brick, non-corrosive metal, or any other material approved by the
Building Inspector.
   (4)   The mobile home shall be placed on a stand that shall be improved to
provide adequate support for the placement and tie-down of the mobile home. The
stand shall not heave, shift, or settle unevenly under the weight of the mobile
home due to frost action, inadequate drainage, vibration, wind, or other force
activity on the structure.
   (5)   Anchors or tie-downs, such as cast-in-place concrete "dead-men,"
eyelets imbedded in concrete, screw augers, or arrow head anchors, shall be
placed at each corner of the mobile home stand and at intervals and of such
strength as required to conform to the requirements of the North Carolina State
Building Code.
   (6)   Sufficient information shall be supplied to the Building Inspector to
determine whether the provisions of this policy have been met. If an
improvement permit from the County Health Department is required, no inspection
shall be made until the Building Inspector has received a copy of the permit.
   (c)   If the Building Inspector shall determine that any violations of this
policy exist, he shall give written notice of such violations to the owner of
the mobile home and/or mobile home park. If, after a reasonable time, to be
determined by the Building Inspector, such violations are not corrected, water
service from the Town shall be terminated.
Section 5-1022 through 5-1030 reserved.

ARTICLE A
Sewer System
Section 5-2001 Board to regulate sewer system.
   The sewer system of the Town shall be under the control of, and the duty of
prescribing and enforcing a full compliance with all the rules and regulations
governing all connections with the public sewer and water system shall be
vested in, the Board or its authorized agent.
   Cross Reference: Powers and duties of Board relative to water and sewer
system, Charter, section
4-9.
Section 5-2002 Separate connections required.
   Each individual business or residential building or structure shall install
a separate sewer connection.
Section 5-2003 Water and sewer required.
   (a)   All owners of improved property located within the corporate limits
and upon or within a reasonable distance of any sewer collection line owned and
operated by the Town shall connect their premises with the Town sewer system.
   (b)   Upon completion of any extension of the public sanitary system of the
Town, the clerk may be directed to
send notice to the owners of property which can thereby be served to make
connection with said system.
   (c)   The charge made for the cost of the connection to the public sanitary
sewer system shall be paid to the Town prior to the time such connection is
made.
   (d)   No outdoor privies may be hereafter constructed on or near any sewer
line, and the Board may require and enforce immediate abandonment of any such
privy.
   State Law Reference: Authority to require connections, G.S. 160A-317.
Section 5-2004 Sewer rates.
   Sewer connection charges shall be determined from time to time by the Board
and shall be kept on file in the office of the clerk.
Section 5-2005 Tampering with or obstructing sewer lines prohibited.
   No person shall tamper with or harm in any manner whatsoever any sewer line,
main or any appurtenance thereto. No person shall throw or deposit any material
or substance in any sewer line that will in any manner obstruct such line.
Section 5-2006 Work on sewer system.
   All work on the sewer system and all connections or disconnections there to
shall be performed by the authorized employees of the Town or their
representatives or plumbers approved by the Town. All work shall be performed
in accordance with the plumbing code of the State and the Town and such
amendments thereto that the Board may from time to time adopt.
Section 5-2007 Commercial establishments.
   All commercial establishments that deposit or may deposit grease, oil, sand,
or similar materials that create blockages in the sewer system shall at their
own expense install an inline device, such as a tank-type grease trap, bar
screen, etc., as prescribed and approved by the plumbing inspector. The device
shall be cleaned, pumped, or maintained on a regular schedule or when needed.
The plumbing inspector may determine a maintenance schedule and require
documentation, records, or reports of the maintenance performed.
(Ord. of 10/10/00)
Section 5-2008 through 5-2010 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Use of Sanitary Sewer
(Reserved)
CHAPTER 3
Water and Sewer Extensions
Section
5-3001   Application for and approval of extensions required.
Section
5-3002   General extension requirements.
Section
5-3003   Financing extensions within corporate limits.
Section
5-3004   Financing extensions outside corporate limits.
Section
5-3005   Specifications, ownership.
Section
5-3006   Additional subdivision improvement requirement.
Section
5-3007   Extension of water and or sewer service beyond municipal limits
Section 5-3001 Application for and approval of extensions required.
   (a)   Any property owner, or owners, desiring water or sanitary sewer
service shall apply in writing to the Board requesting the extension of water
or sanitary sewer service or both. No request for the extension of services
shall be considered unless submitted in writing in accordance with the
requirements of this chapter.
   (b)   The Town may require the applicant to submit as part of the written
application such information, plans or other data as may be required to
adequately determine if the requirements of this article are to be met.
   (c)   When application is made for a water or sewer extension or both to
serve an area or development that is planned as part of a larger development
project or subdivision, all of which is not to be developed at the time
application is made, the owner or owners shall submit plans in sufficient
detail in order to determine the size and type facilities which will be
necessary to serve the entire development or subdivision when completed.
   (d)   No extension to the water or sanitary sewer system of the Town shall
be made and no application shall be approved except in accordance with the
requirements of this chapter.
Section 5-3002 General extension requirements.
   All extensions of either water or sanitary sewer service shall be governed
by the following:
   (1)   The minimum distance for any extension of a water main or sanitary
sewer main shall be determined by the Board. In general, the minimum distance
for extensions shall be one (1) platted block, or in the case of water mains
from main line valve to valve and in the case of sanitary sewer extension from
manhole to manhole.
   (2)   The size of water mains and sanitary sewer mains to be installed and
the other required system facilities shall be determined by the Board in
accordance with the recognized standards and accepted engineering practices and
design and in accordance with applicable system plans adopted by the Board.
Section 5-3003 Financing extensions within corporate limits.
   (a)   Extensions to Approved Subdivisions or Developed Property.
   (1)   When application is received requesting the extension of water or
sanitary sewer service or both to serve property within the corporate limits
which is developed or has been previously approved as a subdivision, or where
streets have previously been dedicated and accepted by the Town, and where such
area is not part of a new subdivision which has not been approved by the Town,
the Manager or other person designated by the Manager shall estimate the cost
of the project and present the application for such extension, the estimated
cost and other required information to the Board for approval. If the
application is approved by the Board and subject to the availability of funds,
the Town will install or have installed by contract under its supervision the
extensions which have been approved, and such extension shall be financed in
accordance with this subsection.
   (2)   When an approved water or sanitary sewer extension project has been
completed and the total cost thereof has been determined,              percent
of the total cost of such water or sanitary sewer extension or both shall be
assessed against the property owners whose property abuts upon such extension
at an equal rate per front foot in accordance with and under the authority
granted to the Town by G.S. 160A-216 et seq. The remaining            percent
of the total cost of such extensions shall be borne by the Town from funds
appropriated for this purpose.
   (3)   Any property owner or owners shall have the opportunity to pay his or
their proportionate share of the cost of such extensions after the assessment
roll is confirmed rather than paying his or their share in equal annual
installments with interest as required by the statute.
   (b)   Extensions to Proposed Developments or Subdivisions.
   (1)   When an application is received requesting the extension of water or
sanitary sewer service or both to proposed developments or subdivisions within
the corporate limits which have not been approved by the Board, the Manager or
other person designated by the Board shall estimate the cost of the project and
present the application for such extension, the estimated cost and other
required information to the Board for their approval. If the application is
approved and subject to the approval of the development or subdivision by the
Town, and subject to the availability of funds, the Town will install or have
installed by contract under its supervision such extensions which shall be
financed in accordance with this subsection.
   (2)   Prior to the beginning of any construction, the property owner or
owners shall advance to the Town funds in an amount equal to                 
percent of the total estimated cost of the proposed extensions. Upon receipt of
such funds, a written contract shall be entered into by and between the Town
and the property owner or owners, under which the Town will use such funds upon
the following terms and conditions.
   a.   The funds shall be deposited in a special account of the Town for which
a separate accounting will be made.
   b.   At the time construction of the extension is completed and the total
cost thereof is determined, if the amount deposited exceeds                
percent of the total cost, that portion in excess of the amount deposited will
be refunded to the owner or owners without interest. If the amount deposited is
less than                  percent of the total cost, the owner or owners shall
pay such additional amount to the Town and this condition shall be a part of
the written contract.
   c.   In lieu of depositing the required funds, the owner or owners may
provide a surety bond or some other form of security that will insure payment
to the Town of the owner's or owners' proportionate share of the cost of
extension in accordance with this chapter.
   d.   No refund or reimbursement of funds shall be made to the owner or
owners who pay               percent of the total cost of extension under the
requirements of this subsection except as provided for in paragraph b. above.
   (3)   The Town will finance from funds appropriated for this purpose the
remaining              percent of the total cost of extension to and within
such proposed developments or subdivisions.
   (c)   Facilities Excluded in Determining Owner's Share of Cost.
   (1)   When the Town determines that it is advisable to install larger size
facilities than are necessary to serve the property requesting such extension,
the difference in the cost of the larger size facilities over and above the
cost of the facilities required to serve the property requesting such extension
shall be paid for by the Town and excluded from the total cost to be shared by
the property owner and the Town as provided for herein.
   (2)   Fire hydrants, pumping stations, and other system facilities installed
for general public use which are expressly identified in the application or
agreement approved by the Board shall be paid for by the Town and excluded from
the total cost to be shared by the property owner or owners as provided for
herein.
   (d)   Exceptions Authorized.
   Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the Board from extending water or
sanitary sewer mains or both within the corporate limits on their own motion
without receipt of an application from property owners, and to assess the cost
of such extensions in accordance with subsection (a) of section
5-3003 of this chapter when, in the opinion of the Board, the general public
interest demands such extension of service.
Section 5-3004 Financing extensions outside corporate limits.
   (a)   All applications for water and sewer extensions outside the corporate
limits shall be made in the same manner and under the same requirements as
provided for in sections
5-3001 and
5-3002 of this chapter.
   (b)   If an application is approved by the Board, the owner or owners shall
be required to pay              percent of the total cost of all extensions.
Provided, the Town may participate to the extent agreed upon by the Board in
the cost of larger size mains that are in excess of the size mains required to
serve the project. No reimbursement shall be made upon annexation and all water
and sewer lines connected to the Town system and located outside the corporate
limits shall become the property of the Town at the time such facilities are
connected.
   (c)   Prior to the beginning of any construction, the owner or owners shall
deposit with the Town funds in an amount equal to                 percent of
the total estimated cost of such extensions. Upon receipt of such funds a
written contract shall be entered into by and between the Town and the property
owner or owners in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. Such
contract shall provide that in the event the funds deposited exceed the amount
of the total extension cost when completed, then that portion in excess of the
total cost will be refunded to the owner or owners without interest. Such
contract shall also provide that if the amount deposited is less than the total
cost, when completed, the owner or owners shall pay such additional amount to
the Town.
   (d)   In lieu of depositing funds the owner or owners may execute a surety
bond guaranteeing payment for such extension or the owner or owners may have
such extension work performed under private contract with the approval of the
Board, provided, the work is to be performed in accordance with all
construction requirements of the Town and subject to inspection and approval of
the Town.
   (e)   In the event the property for which application has been made for
water or sewer service is continuous to the corporate limits and the owner or
owners of such property agree to annexation and in the event such property is
annexed to the Town, extensions may be made to such property and the cost
thereof financed in accordance with the requirements of section
5-3003(a) or
5-3003(b) of this chapter, whichever is applicable.
Section 5-3005 Specifications, ownership.
   Any water mains or sanitary sewer mains extended under the provisions of
this chapter shall be installed and constructed in accordance with the approved
plans, specifications and other requirements of the Town. All facilities
installed under the provisions of this chapter, whether within or outside the
corporate limits shall become the sole property of the Town and under its
jurisdiction and control for any and all purposes whatsoever at the time such
facilities are connected to the Town system. When required, the property owner
or owners shall grant to the Town such utility easements as the Town may
require. In addition, a deed to the Town for water and/or sewer facilities
installed which are located outside the corporate limits, the cost of which is
borne by individual property owners, shall be executed prior to the time any
extensions provided for in this chapter are connected to the Town systems.
Section 5-3006 Additional subdivision improvement requirement.
   The Board may in its discretion, as a condition under which water or sewer
service or both will be extended, require the owner or owners of a proposed
subdivision to enter into an agreement to improve the proposed streets therein
at their own expense and in accordance with the ordinances then in force
governing the acceptance of public streets for the Town. If required, this
section shall apply to subdivisions which are located either within or outside
the corporate limits of the Town.
Section 5-3007 Extension of water and or sewer service beyond municipal limits.
   No water and or sewer service shall be provided to any property outside of
the municipal limits of the Town and no subdivision plat shall be recorded for
any property outside the municipal limits for which water and or sewer service
will be provided except upon compliance with one of the following conditions:
   (a)   If the property is contiguous to the municipal limits of the Town or
if it is not contiguous but meets the requirements of a satellite annexation
(G.S. §§ 160A-58 through 160A-58.6), prior to receiving water and or sewer
service or recording a subdivision plat, the property owners shall irrevocably
petition for annexation of the property into the municipal limits of the Town.
Subsequent action shall be at the discretion of the Town Board.
   (b)   If the property is not contiguous to the municipal limits of the Town
and satellite annexation cannot be accomplished, or it is not approved by the
Town Board of Aldermen, the property owners shall enter into a binding written
agreement with the Town for the annexation thereof at such future date as the
property shall be contiguous to the municipal limits of the Town or meets the
requirements of a satellite annexation, as is approved by the Town Board of
Aldermen.
   (c)   The above requirements shall not exempt any property owner(s) from
other building, zoning, subdivision, or ordinance requirement(s) as proscribed
by the Town of Canton.
(Ord. of 10/28/08)
CHAPTER 4
Reimbursement Agreements
Section
5-4001   Intent and purpose; authority.
Section
5-4002   Jurisdiction.
Section
5-4003   Full force and effect.
Section
5-4004   Interpretation and intent.
Section
5-4005   Funding.
Section 5-4001 Intent and purpose, authority.
   (a)   The Town of Canton Board of Aldermen/women believes infrastructure
projects are essential to promote the creation and attraction of new
businesses, expansion and retention of existing business to stimulate job
opportunities and to improve the quality of life in Canton. Providing resources
for economic development projects can increase local sales and property tax
base of the Town of Canton, Haywood County and possibly surrounding
municipalities.
   (b)   The purpose of this chapter is to give the Canton Board of Aldermen/
women the authority to enter into Reimbursement Agreements pursuant to G.S. §
160A-499.
(Ord. of 4/7/16)
Section 5-4002 Jurisdiction.
   This chapter is and shall be applicable to all areas within the corporate
limits of Canton, North Carolina.
(Ord. of 4/7/16)
Section 5-4003 Full force and effect.
   If any portion of this chapter shall be determined to be invalid,
unconstitutional or otherwise ineffective, such ruling shall not affect the
remainder and other parts and clauses of this chapter, and the same shall
remain in full force and effect.
(Ord. of 4/7/16)
Section 5-4004 Interpretation and intent.
   (a)   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to conflict with the
provisions of the North Carolina General Statutes. In the event of an ambiguity
or conflict between this Ordinance and the provisions of the North Carolina
General Statutes, the latter shall prevail.
   (b)   The chapter shall not be construed to hold the Town of Canton
responsible for any defect of the developer's or property owner's technical
compliance with G.S. Chapter 143, Article 8.
   (c)   The Town of Canton shall have authority to enter into Reimbursement
Agreements such that a developer or property owner may contract with the Town
of Canton to construct an improvement which, had the Town constructed, would be
subject to competitive bidding regulations under G.S. Chapter 143, Article 8.
Such Reimbursement Agreement authorized by G.S. § 160A-499 shall not be subject
to G.S. Chapter 143, Article 8 except as provided by G.S. § 160A-499. Developer
or property owner who is a party to a Reimbursement Agreement with the Town of
Canton shall solicit bids in accordance with G.S. Chapter 143, Article 8 when
awarding contracts for work that would have required competitive bidding if the
contract had been awarded by the Town of Canton.
   (d)   The Town of Canton is also authorized to participate jointly in
Reimbursement Agreements with other municipalities or counties and a developer
or property owner so long as the project is determined to be in the best
interest of the Town of Canton.
(Ord. of 4/7/16)
Section 5-4005 Funding.
   The Town of Canton may provide for such reimbursements to be paid from any
lawful source, including the Town's unrestricted general fund.
(Ord. of 4/7/16)

ARTICLE D Peddling and Soliciting
Section
