ARTICLE A
Adoption of Regulatory Codes
Section 9-1001 Scope of Regulatory Codes.
   The provisions of this chapter and of the regulatory codes herein adopted
shall apply to the following:
   (1)   The location, design, materials, equipment, construction,
reconstruction, alteration, repair, maintenance, moving, demolition, removal,
use, and occupancy of every building or structure or any appurtenances
connected or attached to such building or structure;
   (2)   The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and maintenance of
plumbing systems consisting of house sewers, building drains, waste and vent
systems, hot and cold water supply systems, and all fixtures and appurtenances
thereof;
   (3)   The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and maintenance of
mechanical systems consisting of heating, ventilating, air conditioning, and
refrigeration systems, fuel burning equipment, and appurtenances thereof; and
   (4)   The installation, erection, alteration, repair, use and maintenance of
electrical systems and appurtenances thereof.
Section 9-1002 Building Code adopted.
   The 1967, or later edition of the North Carolina State Building Code (Volume
I, General Construction), as adopted by the North Carolina Building Code
Council and as amended, is hereby adopted by reference as fully as though set
forth herein; including Chapter 4, Permits and Certificates, 401.1-603.19.5,
including any future changes or additions.
(Ord. of 2/23/93)
Section 9-1003 Plumbing Code adopted.
   The 1967, or later edition of the North Carolina Plumbing Code (North
Carolina State Building Code, Volume II, Plumbing) as adopted by the North
Carolina Building Code Council and as amended, is hereby adopted by reference
as fully as though set forth herein.
Section 9-1004 Heating Code adopted.
   The 1967, or later edition of the North Carolina Heating Code (North
Carolina State Building Code, Volume III, Heating) as adopted by the North
Carolina Building Code Council and as amended, is hereby adopted by reference
as fully as though set forth herein.
Section 9-1005 Electrical Code Adopted.
   The 1967, or later edition of the North Carolina Electrical Code (North
Carolina State Building Code, Volume IV, Electrical) as adopted by the North
Carolina Building Code Council and as amended, is hereby adopted by reference
as fully as though set forth herein.
Section 9-1006 Residential Building Code.
   The 1968, or later edition of the North Carolina Uniform Residential
Building Code (North Carolina State Building Code, Volume I-B, Residential), as
adopted by the North Carolina Building Code Council, is hereby adopted by
reference as fully as though set forth herein.
Section 9-1007 Amendments to codes.
   Amendments to the regulatory codes adopted by reference herein, which are
from time to time adopted and published by the agencies or organizations
referred to herein shall be effective in the Town at the time such amendments
are filed with the Town clerk or building inspector as provided in section
9-1009.
Section 9-1008 Compliance with codes.
   (a)   All buildings or structures which are hereafter constructed,
reconstructed, erected, altered, extended, enlarged, repaired, demolished, or
moved shall conform to the requirements, minimum standards, and other
provisions of either the North Carolina State Building Code, General
Construction, Volume I or the North Carolina State Building Code, Volume I-B,
Residential, whichever is applicable, or of both if both are applicable.
   (b)   Every building or structure intended for human habitation, occupancy,
or use shall have plumbing, plumbing systems, or plumbing fixtures installed,
constructed, altered, extended, repaired, or reconstructed in accordance with
the minimum standards, requirements, and other provisions of the North Carolina
Plumbing Code (North Carolina State Building Code, Volume II, Plumbing).
   (c)   All mechanical systems consisting of heating, ventilating, air
conditioning, and refrigeration systems, fuel burning equipment, and
appurtenances shall be installed, erected, altered, repaired, used and
maintained in accordance with the minimum standards, requirements, and other
provisions of the North Carolina Heating Code (North Carolina State Building
Code, Volume III, Heating).
   (d)   All electrical wiring, installations and appurtenances shall be
erected, altered, repaired, used and maintained in accordance with the minimum
standards, requirements, and other provisions of the North Carolina Electrical
Code (North Carolina State Building Code, Volume IV, Electrical).
Section 9-1009 Copies of codes filed with clerk.
   An official copy of each regulatory code adopted herein, and official copies
of all amendments thereto, shall be kept on file in the office of the Town
clerk or building inspector. The copies shall be the official copies of the
codes and the amendments.
Section 9-1010 through 9-1020 reserved.
ARTICLE B
Inspection Department
Section 9-1021 Organization of department.
   The inspection department of the Town shall consist of a building inspector,
and may also include a plumbing inspector, a heating-air conditioning
inspector, an electrical inspector, and such other inspectors or deputy or
assistant inspectors as may be authorized by the Board. The Town manager may in
his discretion designate a department head.
Section 9-1022 General duties of department and inspectors.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the inspection department to enforce all of
the provisions of this chapter and of the regulatory codes adopted herein, and
to make all inspections necessary to determine whether or not the provisions of
this chapter and such codes are being met.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the inspection department to inspect all
dwelling units as they become vacant or at such time as the occupancy at the
unit is changed.
(Ord. of 1/26/88)
Section 9-1023 Conflicts of interest.
   No officer or employee of the inspection department shall be financially
interested in the furnishing of labor, material, or appliances for the
construction, alteration, or maintenance of a building or any part thereof, or
in the making of plans or specifications therefor, unless he is the owner of
the building. No officer or employee of the inspection department shall engage
in any work which is inconsistent with his duties or with the interests of the
Town.
Section 9-1024 Reports and records.
   The inspection department and each inspector shall keep complete, permanent,
and accurate records in convenient form of all applications received, permits
issued, inspections, and reinspections made, and all other work and activities
of the inspection department. Periodic reports shall be submitted to the
manager/Board, and to other agencies, as required.
Section 9-1025 Inspection procedure.
   (a)   The inspection department shall inspect all buildings and structures
and work therein for which a permit of any kind has been issued as often as
necessary in order to determine whether the work complies with this chapter and
the appropriate codes.
   (b)   When deemed necessary by the appropriate inspector, materials, and
assemblies may be inspected at the point of manufacture or fabrication, or
inspections may be made by approved and recognized inspection organizations;
provided, no approval shall be based upon reports of the organizations unless
the same are in writing and certified by a responsible officer of the
organization.
   (c)   All holders of permits, or their agents, shall notify the inspection
department and the appropriate inspector at each of the following stages of
construction so that approval may be given before work is continued:
   (1)   Foundation inspection is to be made after trenches are excavated and
the necessary reinforcement and forms are in place, and before concrete is
placed. Drilled footings, piles, and similar types of foundations shall be
inspected as installed.
   (2)   Framing inspection is to be made after all structural framing is in
place and all roughing-in of plumbing, electrical and heating has been
installed; after all fire blocking, chimneys, bracing and vents are installed;
but before any of the structure is enclosed or covered. Poured in place
concrete structural elements shall be inspected before each pour of any
structural member.
   (3)   Fireproofing inspection is to be made after all areas required to be
protected by fireproofing are lathed, but before the plastering or other
fireproofing is applied.
   (4)   Final inspection is to be made after building or structure has all
doors hung, fixtures set, and is ready for occupancy, but before the building
is occupied.
Section 9-1026 Oversight not to legalize violation.
   No oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of any inspector or other
official or employee of the inspection department shall be deemed to legalize
the violation of any provision of this chapter or any provision of any
regulatory code herein adopted.
Section 9-1027 Powers of inspection officials.
   (a)   Authority. Inspectors are hereby authorized, empowered, and directed
to enforce all the provisions of this chapter and the regulatory codes herein
adopted.
   (b)   Right-of-entry. With an appropriate warrant or permission from the
owner or occupant, inspectors shall have the right-of-entry on any premises
within the jurisdiction of the regulatory codes herein adopted at reasonable
hours for the purpose of inspection or enforcement of the requirements of this
chapter and the applicable regulatory codes.
   (c)   Stop orders. Whenever any building or structure or part thereof is
being demolished, constructed, reconstructed, altered, or repaired in a
hazardous manner, or in violation of any provision of this chapter or any other
Town ordinance, or in violation of any provisions of any regulatory code herein
adopted, or in violation of the terms of the permit or permits issued therefor,
or in such manner as to endanger life or property, the appropriate inspector
may order the work to be immediately stopped. The order shall be in writing to
the owner of the property or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, and
shall state the reasons therefor and the conditions under which the work may be
resumed.
Section 9-1028 Fee.
   There shall be a fee of $35 for inspections requested by realtors and the
general public.
(Ord. of 1/26/88)
Section 9-1029 through 9-1040 reserved.
ARTICLE C
Enforcement
Section 9-1041 Registration of contractors.
   Every person carrying on the business of building contractor, plumbing
contractor, heating-air conditioning contractor, or electrical contractor
within the Town shall register at the office of the inspection department,
giving name and place of business.
Section 9-1042 Bond required of contractors.
   Every person required to register at the office of the inspection department
under the preceding section may be required to give a good and sufficient bond
to be approved by the Town conditioned upon faithful performance of duty in
doing any work which he may have contracted to do; and to indemnify the Town
against loss in any manner whatsoever for any unskillful or negligent work or
conduct in the performance of the duties imposed by the provisions of this
chapter or any regulatory code herein adopted, or any damage to any utility
lines, streets, or sidewalks in the Town, or for the use of defective or
improper material in the work, or for the payment of any inspector or other
fees required by this chapter.
Section 9-1043 Permits required.
   (a)   Building permit.
   (1)   No person shall commence or proceed with the construction,
reconstruction, alteration, repair, removal, or demolition of any building or
other structure, or any part thereof, without a written permit therefor from
the building inspector; provided, however, that no building permit shall be
required for work, the total cost of which does not exceed $100, and which does
not involve any change of the structural parts or the stairways, elevators,
fire escapes or other means of egress to the building or the structure in
question.
   County Board of Health approval of a septic tank is required where the
sewage system cannot be connected to the Town sewer.
   (2)   In all cases of removal or demolition of a building or structure, a
good and sufficient bond may be required to be posted by the property owner or
by his contractor at the time of application for a permit, to insure complete
removal or demolition, including all rubble and debris. Failure on the part of
the property owner or his contractor to completely demolish, remove, and clear
the premises, after 30 days' notice by the building inspector, shall be cause
for forfeiture of the bond.
   (b)   Plumbing permit. No person shall commence or proceed with the
installation, extension, or general repair of any plumbing system without a
written permit therefor from the plumbing inspector; provided, however, no
permit shall be required for minor repairs or replacements on the house side of
a trap to an installed system of plumbing if the repairs or replacements do not
disrupt the original water supply or the waste or ventilating systems.
   (c)   Heating-air conditioning permit. No person shall commence or proceed
with the installation, extension, alteration or general repair of any heating
or cooling equipment system without a written permit from the heating-air
conditioning inspector; provided, however, no permit shall be required for
minor repairs or minor burner services or filter replacements of warm air
furnaces or cooling systems.
   (d)   Electrical permit. No person shall commence or proceed with the
installation, extension, alteration, or general repair of any electrical
wiring, devices, appliances or equipment without a written permit therefor from
the electrical inspector; provided, however, no permit shall be required for
minor repair work such as the replacement of lamps or the connection of
portable devices to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed;
provided, further, no permit shall be required from the installation,
alteration, or repair of the electrical wiring, devices, appliances, and
equipment installed by or for an electrical public utility corporation for the
use of such corporation in the generation, transmission, distribution, or
metering of electrical energy.
Section 9-1044 Application for permit.
   Written application shall be made for all permits required by this article
and shall be made on forms provided by the inspection department. The
application shall be made by the owner of the building or structure affected or
by his authorized agent or representative, and, in addition to such other
information as may be required by the appropriate inspector to enable him to
determine whether the permit applied for should be issued, shall show the
following:
   (1)   Name, residence, and business address of owner;
   (2)   Name, residence, and business of authorized representative or agent,
if any; and
   (3)   Name and address of the constructor, if any, together with evidence
that he has obtained a certificate from the appropriate state licensing board
for such contractors, if such be required for the work involved in the permit
for which application is made.
Section 9-1045 Issuance of permit.
   When proper application for a permit has been made, and the appropriate
inspector is satisfied that the application and the proposed work comply with
the provisions of this chapter and the appropriate regulatory codes, he shall
issue the permit, upon payment of the proper fee or fees as hereinafter
provided in section
9-1049.
Section 9-1046 Revocation of permits.
   The appropriate inspector may revoke and require the return of any permit by
notifying the permit holder in writing stating the reason for the revocation.
Permits shall be revoked for any material departure from the approved
application, plans, or specifications; for refusal or failure to comply with
proper orders of the inspector; for refusal or failure to comply with
requirements of this chapter and the appropriate regulatory codes; or for false
statements or misrepresentations made in securing the permit.
Section 9-1047 Time limitations on validity of permits.
   All permits issued under this article shall expire by limitation six (6)
months after the date of issuance if the work authorized by the permit has not
been commenced. If after commencement the work is discontinued for a period of
12 months, the permit therefor shall immediately expire. No work authorized by
any permit which has expired shall thereafter be performed until a new permit
therefor has been secured.
Section 9-1048 Changes in work.
   After a permit has been issued, changes or deviations from the terms of the
application and permit, or changes or deviations from the plans or
specifications involving any work under the jurisdiction of this article or of
any regulatory code adopted herein, shall not be made until specific written
approval of such changes or deviations has been obtained from the appropriate
inspector.
Section 9-1049 Permit fees.
   Fees for permits shall be based upon the total estimated cost of the
proposed work, including all subcontracts if any, but in no case shall the
total estimated cost be less than the market value of similar completed work in
the Town as determined by the appropriate inspector or inspectors. Permit fees
shall be established by the Board, and as follows:

ARTICLE D
Condemnation, Repair and Demolition of Unsafe Buildings
Section 9-1061 Duty of Inspection department.
   The inspection department shall be charged with enforcing the provisions of
G.S. 160A-426 through G.S. 160A-434, relating to the condemnation, repair and
demolition of unsafe buildings, upon the direction of the Board.
Section 9-1062 through 9-1070 reserved.
ARTICLE E
Insulation Contractors
Section 9-1071 Authority.
   This article is adopted pursuant to Chapter 703, North Carolina Session Laws
of 1977, and Section 160A-I94 of the General Statutes of North Carolina.
(Ord. of 12/27/77. Sec. 2 )
Section 9-1072 Required license.
   On and after January 1. 1978. no person, firm, or corporation may for a
consideration install. alter, or restore within the Town any insulation or
other materials or energy utilization equipment designed or intended to meet
the State Building Code requirements for insulation and energy utilization
standards who is not either (i) licensed as a contractor to do the proposed
work under Chapter 87 of the General Statutes, (ii) working under the
supervision of a registered architect or professional engineer, (iii) an owner
working upon his own building. or (iv) licensed under this article.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec. 2)
Section 9-1073 Applications.
   Every person desiring a license under this article shall submit an
application for such license to the Town Clerk conforming to the following
requirements:
   (1)   Form of application. Each application shall be a written statement
upon forms provided by the Town Clerk.
   (2)   Contents of application. Each application shall contain the following
information:
   a.   Name and home address of the applicant, if an individual, or home
office address, if a corporation or partnership:
   b.   Names and home addresses of the partners. if a partnership:
   c.   Names and home addresses of the officers and directors, if a
corporation.
   d.   Place where the proposed business is to be located.
   e.   Complete record of all convictions of felonies or acts involving
dishonesty, fraud, or deceit by the applicant or any employee, partner,
officer. or director of the applicant, whether in this or any other state or
jurisdiction:
   f.   Complete record of all licenses held by the applicant or any employee.
partner. officer, or director of the applicant authorizing activities of the
type authorized herein or other activities involving construction, alteration,
or modification of buildings and structures:
   g.   Information as to the circumstances in which any local, state, or
federal government or agency has refused. suspended, or revoked a license of
the type described in paragraph f. to the applicant or any employee, partner,
officer, or director of the applicant.
   (3)   Fees. Each application shall be accompanied by a fee of five dollars
($5.00) for such license, such amount to be for the fiscal year and prorated by
quarters to the end of such year.
   (4)   False statements. False statements on any application for a license
shall be grounds for immediate revocation or denial of such license.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec.3)
Section 9-1074 Procedure for issuance.
   (a)   Review by town officers. Each application received by the Town Clerk
shall be promptly forwarded to the Inspector for review.
   (b)   Licensing agency. The application and any comments and recommendations
relating thereto shall be considered by the Inspector, who shall then issue or
deny the license pursuant to the following standards.
   (c)   Standards. The Inspector shall issue the license unless it shall find
that the applicant or any employee. partner, officer, or director of the
applicant:
   (1)   Has been convicted within the last three (3) years of a felony or an
act involving dishonesty, fraud, or deceit whether in this or any other state
or jurisdiction;
   (2)   Has been refused a license to do the type of work authorized herein or
has had a license suspended or revoked by any local, state, or federal
government or agency and such government or agency has not subsequently granted
or restored such license:
   (3)   Has knowingly made a false statement in the application:
   (4)   Has failed to post the bond or other security required by section
9-1075.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec. 4)
Section 9-1075 Bond required.
   (a)   Before a license shall be issued to any applicant, the applicant shall
post a bond with the Town in the amount of $1,000. In lieu of posting a bond,
the applicant may deposit a cashier's check or cash in the same amount.
   (b)   The security required by subsection (a) shall be available to
indemnify any person for any damage which may accrue by reason of the
applicant's failure to properly provide or install insulation, energy
utilization equipment or other materials designed or intended to meet the State
Building Code Standards for insulation and energy utilization.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec. 5)
Section 9-1076 Termination and renewal of licenses.
   All licenses issued hereunder shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal
year for which issued. Renewal of such licenses shall be pursuant to the same
procedures and requirements set forth for initial issuance.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec. 6)
Section 9-1077 Suspension; revocation.
   (a)   The Inspector may suspend or revoke any license issued hereunder at
any time upon a showing that the applicant or any employee, partner. officer,
or director of the applicant has (i) knowingly made a false statement in the
application for a license, or (ii) violated the State Building Code
requirements as to insulation or energy utilization equipment or materials,
whether in this or any other jurisdiction, or (iii) been convicted of an act
involving dishonesty. fraud, or deceit with respect to any contract entered
into for work requiring this license.
   (b)   Any licensee whose license is suspended or revoked may appeal the
suspension or revocation to the Mayor and Board of Aldermen. After reasonable
notice to the licensee, the Mayor and Board of Aldermen shall afford the
licensee an opportunity to show why its license should not be suspended or
revoked.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec. 7)
Section 9-1078 Change of locations.
   The location of any licensed business may be changed, provided 10 days
notice thereof is given to the Town and operation at such new location does not
violate any applicable State or local law, ordinance, or regulation.
(Ord. of 12/27/78, Sec. 8)
Section 9-1079 Required permit; fee; exceptions.
   (a)   On and after January 1, 1978, no person, firm, or corporation may for
a consideration install, alter, or restore any insulation or other materials or
energy utilization equipment designed or intended to meet the State Building
Code requirements for insulation and energy utilization without first securing
a special insulation and energy utilization permit from the Building Inspector
for each item of work, which permit shall evidence compliance with the
insulation and energy utilization standards of the State Building Code.
   (b)   There shall be a fee of $5.00 for each permit issued.
   (c)   The following shall not be required to obtain the permit required by
subsection (a):
   (1)   an owner working upon his own building;
   (2)   an installer working under the supervision of a registered architect
or professional engineer, when the work is being performed under a general
building permit;
   (3)   a contractor licensed to do the proposed work under Chapter 87 of the
General Statutes, when the work is being performed under a general building
permit.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec. 9)
Section 9-1080 Penalties.
   Any person, firm, or corporation violating the provisions of this article
shall be subject to all the applicable punishment, penalties, and equitable
relief provided for by Section 160A-175 of the General Statutes and Chapter
703, North Carolina Session Laws of 1977.
(Ord. of 12/27/77, Sec. 10)
ARTICLE F
Additional Regulations
Section 9-1100 Street numbers to be displayed.
   Every residence and business in the town shall have at least a three (3")
inch number or plaque plainly placed on the street side of their property
showing the number of their residence or business.
(Ord. of 4/22/86; Amended by Ord. of 10/22/96)
ARTICLE G
Building Maintenance Standards
Section 9-1200 Title.
   This Article shall be known as "Building Maintenance Standards" for the Town
of Canton, and may be cited as such, and will be referred to hereinafter as
"this Article."
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1201 Purpose.
   It is the purpose and intent of the Canton Town Mayor and Board of Aldermen,
through the adoption of this Article, to establish a set of building
maintenance standards for all commercial properties as a mechanism to preserve
the historic integrity and vitality of Canton's business districts, eliminate
blight, deter crime, protect property values, reduce the risk of damage from
fire, flooding, or other hazards, and promote the comfort, happiness, and
emotional stability of residents and businesses alike. In particular, the Town
finds that vacant properties and those exhibiting evidence of abandonment pose
special risks to the health, safety, and welfare of the community and therefore
require certain regulatory provisions be enacted. This Article is not intended
to create a hardship for the existing property owner of vacant or occupied
commercial buildings but instead to aid in Town efforts to promote the
viability and marketability of the community.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1202 Findings; authority.
   (a)   Pursuant to the Town's general ordinance making power conferred by
G.S. § 160A-174, it is hereby found that the Town of Canton contains commercial
structures which are not maintained sufficiently to provide for the health,
safety, and welfare of its citizens, protect property values, promote tourism
and economic development and preserve the integrity and character of the
community. It is further found, pursuant to G.S. Chapter 160A-439, that there
exist in the Town non-residential (i.e. commercial) buildings or structures
which are unsafe and especially dangerous to life because of susceptibility to
fire failing walls, overloaded floors, defective construction, decay, unsafe
wiring or heating systems, inadequate means of egress, and other causes.
   (b)   In addition, it is hereby found and declared, that there exist in the
Town non-residential (i.e. commercial) buildings or structures which, although
not meeting the classification of unsafe and especially dangerous to life, fail
to fully comply with all the minimum standards for non-residential (i.e.
commercial) buildings or structural fitness as established herein and,
therefore, have present one or more conditions which are inimical to the public
health, safety, and general welfare of the community and/or adjacent
properties. Such conditions, if not corrected, can lead to deterioration,
dilapidation and blight of non-residential (i.e. commercial) buildings or
structures which render them unsafe and especially dangerous to life.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1203 Scope; jurisdiction.
   The provisions of this Article shall apply to all properties in the C-
1 Central Business, C-2 General Business, C-3 Neighborhood Business, C-
4 Highway Business, I-1 Light Industrial, and I-2 Heavy Industrial Business
Districts of the Town of Canton and its ETJ Extra Territorial Jurisdiction to
the extent applicable by law. Residential properties are not subject to the
provision of this Article.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1204 Definitions.
   For the purposes of this Article, certain words and phrases used in this
Article are defined as follows:
   (1)   Boarding-up means erecting, installing, placing, or maintaining boards
other materials over the doors, windows, or other openings of any commercial
building or structure, whether vacant or occupied, or otherwise securing such
opening by means other than the conventional method used in the original
construction and design of the building or structure located on the property.
   (2)   Building Code means the North Carolina Commercial Building Code.
   (3)   Business days means consecutive business days (Monday-Friday).
   (4)   Commencement of work means all necessary permits have been pulled and
job site activity has commenced including, but not limited to, mobilization,
the delivery of supplies and equipment, and individuals engaged in construction
activity.
   (5)   Days means consecutive calendar days.
   (6)   Deterioration means the condition of a building or part thereof,
characterized by holes, breaks, rot, crumbling, rusting, peeling paint or other
evidence of physical decay or loss of structural integrity.
   (7)   Electrical means all of the following supplies, facilities and
equipment: fixtures, receptacles, electrical panels, equipment and wiring.
   (8)   Evidence of abandonment or neglect means any aesthetic condition that
on its own or combined with other conditions present, would lead a reasonable
person to believe that the property is abandoned and/or property owner has made
no noticeable or meaningful attempt to improve the property and prepare it for
lease or sale. Such conditions include, but are not limited to, overgrown or
dead vegetation, extensively chipped or peeling exterior paint, exterior walls
in poor condition, porches and steps in poor condition, roofs in poor
condition, broken windows and other signs of general disrepair, accumulation of
newspapers, circulars, flyers or mail, past due utility notices or disconnected
utilities, accumulation of trash, junk or debris, the absence of window
covering (i.e. curtains, blinds, or shutters), statements by neighbors,
passersby, delivery agents, government employees that the property is
abandoned, dirty or un-kept appearance of interior.
   (9)   Government agency means any public body having authority over the
Property and residents of the Town, including but not limited to the Town of
Canton, Haywood County, Canton Police Department, Canton Fire Department,
Canton Code Enforcement, Haywood County Sheriffs Office.
   (10)   Government official means any public official representing a public
body which has authority over the property and residents of the Town, including
but not limited to the Town Administrators, Town Code Enforcement Officer, Town
Police Chief, County Building Inspector, County Fire Marshall.
   (11)   Graffiti means any inscriptions, words, figures, paintings, or other
defacements that are written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn,
painted, or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of real property or
improvements thereon without prior authorization of the owner or occupant of
the property by means of any aerosol paint container, broad-tipped marker,
brush.
   (12)   Historic District means the state-designated Canton Historic
District, as listed in the National Register of Historic Places and/or defined
in the ordinances establishing the Canton Historic District.
   (13)   Local means located within forty (40) road or driving miles distance
of the subject property.
   (14)   Non-residential property means any real property used or intended to
be used for anything other than residential property as defined herein.
   (15)   Occupied means occupancy by the owner or any business or individual
whose presence therein is with the consent of the owner with utilities
furnished to the property. This means that a business is currently housed and
operating at the subject property, has applied for and been issued an official
Business License from the Town of Canton.
   (16)   Out of area means located in excess of forty (40) road or driving
miles distance away from the subject property.
   (17)   Owner means any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a
legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official
records of the State of North Carolina or Haywood County as holding title to
the property: or otherwise having control of the property, including the
guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or administrator of
the estate of such person. Additionally, for the purpose of this Article, any
and all trustees in a Deed of Trust shall be considered an owner.
   (18)   Parties in interest means all individuals, associations, and
corporations who have interests of record in a non-residential building or
structure and any who are in possession thereof.
   (19)   Physical valuation means the estimated cost to replace a building in
kind.
   (20)   Plumbing means all of the following supplies, facilities and
equipment: gas pipes, gas burning equipment, water pipes, water heaters,
garbage disposal units, waste pipes, water closets, sinks, installed
dishwashers, lavatories, catch basins, vents and similar fixtures, together
with all connections to water, sewer or gas lines, and water pipes and lines
utilized in conjunction with HVAC equipment.
   (21)   Property means any unimproved or improved real property or portion
thereof, situated in the Town of Canton and includes the buildings or
structures located on the property regardless of condition.
   (22)   Residential property means a building, or portion thereof, designed
exclusively for residential occupancy, including single-family and multi-family
dwellings, mobile and/or manufactured homes, boarding and lodging houses,
apartment houses, and apartment hotels of stand-alone hotels.
   (23)   Securing means such measures as may be directed by the Town Code
Enforcement Officer and/or Town Manager or his/her designee that renders the
property inaccessible to unauthorized persons, including but not limited to the
repairing of fences and walls, chaining or padlocking of gates, the repairing
of doors, windows or other openings.
   (24)   Structural means any and all interior and exterior walls, partitions,
supporting members, joists, rafters, floors, roofs, foundations, piers,
interior and exterior steps, railings, landings, porches or other parts or
appurtenances.
   (25)   Town means the Town of Canton corporate limits and it's Extra
Territorial Jurisdiction (ETJ).
   (26)   Town of Canton Code Enforcement Officer means the person delegated as
such by the Town Manager.
   (27)   Utilities means water, sewer, telephone, natural and propane gas, and
electricity services.
   (28)   Vacant means a property that has not been legally occupied for 120
days.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1205 Commercial property maintenance requirements.
   Properties subject to this Article shall be kept in compliance with the
following maintenance requirements at all times:
   (1)   Exterior surfaces in general.
   a.   The exteriors of a commercial building(s)/structures(s) on the
property; whether vacant or occupied, shall be painted and maintained in a way
that does not exhibit any evidence of abandonment or neglect. All exterior
surfaces, including but not limited to doors, door and window frames, window
mullions and grills, cornices, porches, and trim shall be maintained in good
repair. Exterior wood surfaces, other than decay resistant woods, shall be
protected from the elements and decay by painting or other protective covering
or treatment. Peeling, flaking and chipped paint shall be eliminated and
surfaces repainted. Decayed wood shall be replaced. All siding and masonry
joints shall be maintained, weather resistant and water tight. All windows
shall be properly glazed to eliminate water infiltration. Missing, loose, or
crumbling mortar joints shall be removed and repointed. Missing and rotting
portions of siding shall be replaced. Missing and/or damaged brick(s) shall be
replaced. Leaning, buckling, or separating walls shall be reconstructed or
permanently stabilized to prevent collapse. In addition, any loose stucco shall
be removed and patched. All surfaces shall be free of graffiti.
   b.   Where a wall of a building has become exposed as a result of demolition
of an adjacent building said wall must have all doors, windows, vents or other
similar openings closed with material of the type comprising the wall unless
such doors, windows, vents or other similar openings are to be maintained in
accordance with the provisions of this Article. No protrusions or loose
material shall be in the wall. The exposed wall shall be scaled, cleaned, and
weather sealed or concealed by paint, stucco, or brick to prevent deterioration
of the wall. Any improvements to an exposed wall must be done in a manner and
with materials that will compliment the original character of the building and
that of surrounding properties.
   (2)   Foundational walls. All foundational walls shall be maintained so as
to carry the safe design and operating dead and live loads of the structure and
shall be maintained plumb and free from open cracks and breaks so as not to be
detrimental to public safety and welfare. Proper drainage measures shall be in
place so as to not allow rain water to enter a building/structure and/or its
foundation.
   (3)   Roofs.
   a.   Roofs of commercial buildings, whether vacant or occupied, shall be
maintained so that they are structurally sound and in a safe condition and have
no defects which might admit rain or cause dampness in the interior portions of
the building. All portions, additions or sections of a roof including, but not
limited to, the fascia, eave, soffit, sheathing, rafter tail, barge rafter,
vent screening, gutter, downspout, and metal flashing, shall be complete with
all trim strips, moldings, brackets, braces and supports attached or fastened
in accordance with common building practices or otherwise specified in the
North Carolina Building Code.
   b.   Gutters must be free of vegetation and in good repair. Gutters and down
spouts shall be replaced or repaired as necessary and shall be appropriately
located and securely installed so as not to cause hazard to pedestrians,
vehicular traffic or property.
   c.   Roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent rainwater from causing
dampness or deterioration in the walls or interior portion of the building.
   (4)   Exterior stairways, fire escapes, decks, porches, and balconies.
   a.   Exterior stairways, fire escapes, decks, porches and balconies, and all
appurtenances attached thereto, of a building shall be maintained so that they
are structurally sound, in good repair, with proper anchorage and capable of
supporting the imposed loads. Decks, porches and balconies located on the
property shall be maintained in a way that does not provide evidence of
abandonment or neglect.
   b.   All exterior porches, landings, balconies, stairs and fire escapes
shall be provided with banisters or railing properly designed and maintained in
accord with State Building Code to minimize the hazard of falling, and the same
shall be kept structurally sound, in good repair, free of defects, and clear of
any obstructions to egress.
   (5)   Windows.
   a.   The window(s) of building(s)/structure(s) of the property shall be
intact and operable and shall be maintained in a way that does not provide
evidence of abandonment or neglect. Windows of buildings shall be fully
supplied and maintained with glass window panes or with a substitute approved
by the Town Code Enforcement Officer. Any improvements must be done in a manner
and with materials that will compliment to original character of the building
and surrounding properties. Such glass or substitute material shall be without
cracks, holes or missing panes, and shall be properly glazed. Screens, if
provided, shall be securely fastened to the window and maintained in good
repair. The boarding-up of windows is not an approved substitute material
unless provided for within Section 9-1209 Subsection (3) of this Article.
   b.   All windows shall be free of any evidence of old signage, stickers and/
or decals. Windows must be regularly cleaned in a manner as not to appear
dirty, filthy, or un-kept. Broken or loose mullions shall be replaced.
   (6)   Exterior doors and frames. Exterior doors of commercial building(s)/
structure(s) located on property, whether vacant or occupied, shall be
maintained so that they fit reasonably well within their frames so as to
substantially prevent rain and wind from entering the building. All doors shall
be free of any evidence of old stickers and/or decals. Doors with glass must be
regularly cleaned in a manner as not to appear dirty, filthy, or un-kept. Door
windows and glass doors shall be in good repair in accordance to Section 9-1205
(5).
   (7)   Storefronts and facades. The storefronts and facades of building(s)/
structure(s) shall be maintained in a way that does not provide evidence of
abandonment or neglect. The interiors, when visible to passerby through
storefront windows, shall be maintained in a way that does not exhibit evidence
of abandonment. Any storage within the building(s)/structures(s) shall be
concealed by means of storefront and/or window decor, the addition of displays,
opaque curtains, etc. The spray painting, frosting of, or covering of windows
with newspaper or other forms of construction paper material is not any
acceptable means by which an owner of property may conceal that which is
within.
   (8)   Business identification signs. All business identification signs
located on any commercial property and attached to a building structure shall
be maintained so that they are structurally sound, in good repair, and properly
anchored. Evidence of previous signage such as adhesive, hooks, or hangers
shall be removed. No dilapidated signs or that which is found to be in
disrepair or unsafe shall be allowed to remain on a building structure. New
signage may be placed on a building structure but must conform to the Sign
Ordinance of the Town of Canton. No business identification language, sign or
window ads shall be painted on a building's windows using window markers.
Within sixty (60) days of a property becoming vacant all signs, attached or
otherwise, shall be removed from the building structure.
   (9)   Yards, sidewalks and alleys. The yard(s), sidewalk(s) and alley(s)
adjacent to the property shall be maintained in a way that does not provide
evidence of abandonment or neglect. Premises and exterior property on which a
building is located shall be maintained free from grass, weeds, trash, and
refuse. Paved driveways and parking areas with 50% or greater weed penetration
shall be made weed free.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1206 Commercial property interior maintenance standards.
   (a)   Structural.
   (1)   Walls, partitions, supporting members, sills, joists, rafters or other
structural members shall not list, bow, lean or buckle, shall not be rotted,
deteriorated or damaged, and shall not have holes or cracks which might admit
rodents.
   (2)   Floors and roofs shall have adequate supporting members and strength
to be reasonably safe for the purpose used.
   (3)   Foundations, foundation walls, piers or other foundation supports
shall not be deteriorated or damaged.
   (4)   Interior steps, stairways, railings and landings shall be maintained
in such condition that they will not fall or collapse.
   (b)   Plumbing, electrical and supplied facilities.
   (1)   All plumbing fixtures and pipes shall meet the standards of the State
Plumbing Code and shall be maintained in a state of good repair and in good
working order.
   (2)   All electrical fixtures, receptacles, panels, equipment and wiring
shall be maintained in a state of good repair, safe, capable of being used, and
installed in accordance with the State Electric Code.
   (3)   Every supplied facility, piece of equipment or utility which is
required under this Article or the State Building Code for occupancy or use
shall be so constructed or installed that it will function safely and
effectively and shall be maintained in satisfactory working condition.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1207 Registration requirements for vacant properties.
   (a)   Any vacant commercial property located within the Town's C-1 Central
Business, C-2 General Business, C-3 Neighborhood Business, C-4 Highway
Business, I-1 Light Industrial, and I-2 Heavy Industrial Business Districts and
its Extra Territorial Jurisdiction (ETJ) must be registered by the owner with
the Town, either 1) of the owner of vacant property's own accord before
receiving a Notice of Registration Requirement, or 2) within thirty (30) days
of receiving a Notice of Registration Requirement from the Town of Canton. The
Registration Fee for a vacant commercial property is $50.00 and shall be
renewed annually.
   (b)   The Town will send a Notification of Registration Requirement to the
owner of record of properties that exhibit evidence of abandonment, neglect, or
that are noticeably vacant. The owner shall register property within ten (10)
days by completing and submitting to the Town a Vacant Commercial Property
Registration Form, unless owner can provide clear and convincing evidence to
the Town Code Enforcement Officer within such time period that the property is
not vacant.
   (c)   The registration shall contain:
   (1)   The name of the owner (corporation or individual);
   (2)   The direct street/office mailing address of the owner and P.O. Box (if
applicable); and
   (3)   A direct contact name and phone number.
   (d)   Any changes in the information in C1-C3 of this Section shall be
reported to the Town within thirty (30) days of such change.
   (e)   Registration must be renewed annually.
   (f)   Vacant properties shall remain subject to the annual registration,
maintenance, and security requirements of this Article as long as they remain
vacant.
   (g)   Once the property is no longer vacant or is sold, the owner must
provide written proof to Town of occupancy or sale.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1208 Security requirements for vacant properties.
   Vacant properties subject to this Article shall comply with the following
security requirements.
   (1)   The property shall be maintained in a secure manner so as not to be
accessible to unauthorized persons.
   (2)    This includes, without limitation, the closure and locking of
windows, doors (including but not limited to walk-through, sliding, and
garage), gates, pet doors, and any other such opening of such size that it may
allow a child to access the interior of the property or structure(s).
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1209 Boarding-up structures.
   It is the intention of the Town to limit the number of boarded-up windows,
doors and other openings within commercial districts. The boarding-up of
structures not only poses several concerns related to health, safety, and
welfare but also increases the risk of loss to vacant properties as a result of
damage from fire, flooding, or other hazards. The Town may issue a Boarding-Up
Permit in certain circumstances.
   (1)   Boarding-up Permit. No person, firm, association or corporation shall
erect, install, place, or maintain boards over the doors, windows, or other
opening of any building or structure or otherwise secure such opening by a
means other than the conventional method used in the original construction and
design of the building or structure without first obtaining a valid Boarding-Up
Permit from the Town of Canton, in accordance with this subsection of Chapter
8. Any property with boards existing at the time of the adoption of this
Article will have sixty (60) days from the date of its adoption to submit an
application to the Town of Canton for a permit to continue to board.
   (2)   Issuance of a permit. The Town of Canton may issue a Boarding-Up
Permit only upon satisfaction of the following conditions:
   a.   Submission of a completed Boarding-Up Permit Application by the owner
of the property or his/her authorized representative, including the following
information:
   1.   Name, address and telephone number of the owner;
   2.   Name, address and telephone number of any local agent of the owner;
   3.   Tax parcel identification number of the premises on which the building/
structure is located;
   4.   Common address of the building; and
   5.   Other information as may be required by the Town.
   b.   Payment of the required permit fee by the owner of the property or his/
her authorized representative.
   c.   Submission of a written action plan by the owner of the property or
his/her authorized representative specifying:
   1.   Length of time the owner expects the boarding-up to continue;
   2.   Proposed plan to secure or board-up the structure, including a detailed
description regarding the manner and materials; and
   3.   Detailed description and affirmation that the property owner intends to
replace boarding with windows containing glass panes or with a substitute
material approved by the Town Code Enforcement Officer in accordance to Section
9 -1205(5).
   d.   The Town may conduct an inspection of the subject property to ensure
that the building is boarded-up in accordance with the plan approved by the
Town Code Enforcement Officer.
   (3)   Permit cost. The cost of a Boarding-Up Permit shall $50.00.
   (4)   Regulations.
   a.   A Boarding-Up Permit issued pursuant to this subsection shall authorize
the boarding-up or other securing of a building or structure for a period, not
to exceed ninety (90) days.
   b.   All boarded openings shall be painted with a minimum of two (2) coats
of exterior paint, which is of a color compatible with the exterior color of
the building or structure located on the property.
   c.   Any boarding-up of a building or structure shall be done in a manner
compliant with all applicable building codes.
   d.   Windows broken as a result of damage caused by vandalism, theft, or act
of nature shall be boarded-up immediately and in accordance with the
regulations set forth in this Article, so as to protect public health and
welfare.
   (5)   Exemptions. No Boarding-Up Permit fee shall be required to board-up a
building for up to thirty (30) days in the event of a permitted renovation or
temporary emergency situation, including but not limited to damage caused by
fire, vandalism, theft, or act of nature. In the event an emergency situation
requires a building(s)/structure(s) to be boarded-up for more than thirty (30)
days, it is the responsibility of the owner of the property or his/her
authorized representative to apply for a Boarding-Up Permit.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1210 Burned building(s)/structure(s).
   (a)   Whenever any building or structure is fully or partially burned, the
owner or person in control shall, within sixty (60) days after completion of
the scene investigation by the Fire Department, County Fire Marshall, and/or
insurer of the property, remove from the premises all refuse, debris, and all
charred and partially burned lumber and material.
   (b)   If such building or structure is burned to such an extent that repair
costs would exceed 50% of the fair market value it is rendered incapable of
being repaired, the owner or person in control shall, within sixty (60) days of
conclusion of investigation obtain a demolition permit and remove from the
premises all the remaining portion of the building or structure including the
foundation within (60) days of issuance of the permit or a mutually agreed-
upon, reasonable timeframe between the Town and owner.
   (c)   If the building or structure is to be repaired a building permit shall
be obtained and work shall begin within sixty (60) days of conclusion of
investigation or a mutually agreed-upon, reasonable timeframe between the Town
and owner. Work shall be completed within one hundred eighty (180) days from
the date a permit is obtained or a mutually agreed upon timeframe between the
Town and owner.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1211 Buildings for lease or sale.
   The listing or advertising of a building or structure for lease or sale does
not relieve the property owner from meeting those standards which are set forth
within this Article.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1212 Inspections.
   (a)   Whenever it appears to the Code Enforcement officer that any
commercial building is in violation of one or more provisions of this Article,
s/he shall have the authority to inspect said properties subject to this
Article for compliance. The Code Enforcement Officer shall have authority to
enter upon premises for the purpose of inspecting the same for compliance with
this Article, at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner that will do the
least possible inconvenience to the property owner and customers.
   (b)   All non-residential (i.e. commercial) property owners shall cooperate
with Town staff in the inspection process and allow access to said property/
building. If a building code violation is realized during the inspection
process, Town of Canton staff (Code Enforcement Officer, Town Manager or other
designee) have the duty, and obligation to report such violations to the
Haywood County Building Inspections Department. This may result in additional
remedies being required of the property owner. At any time during the
inspection or subsequent meetings with the property owner to discuss a building
code inspection, Town staff may solicit participation by Haywood County
Building Inspection personnel in an effort to resolve any building code
violations which may exist.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1213 Notice of violation and requirement of hearing.
   If the preliminary investigation discloses evidence of a violations of this
Article, but does not reveal evidence that a building is unsafe and especially
dangerous to life, the Code Enforcement Officer shall issue and cause to be
served upon the owner of and parties in interest in the non-residential (i.e.
commercial) building or structure a Notice of Violation. The Notice of
Violation shall clearly state the violations and required corrective action(s)
to be taken to rectify the situation, and set a date for a hearing.
   (1)   A Hearing shall be scheduled before the Code Enforcement Officer and/
or Town Manager at a place within the Town, scheduled not less than ten (10)
business days nor more than thirty (30) business days after the serving of the
Notice of Violation. The owner and any parties in interest shall have the right
to file an answer to the Notice of Violation and to appear in person or
otherwise, and give testimony at the place and time fixed in the Notice of
Violation. Any person desiring to do so may attend the hearing and give
evidence relevant to the matter being heard. The Rules of Evidence prevailing
in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the Code
Enforcement Officer. Testimony shall be under oath and the owner and parties in
interest shall have the right to cross examine witnesses. During the hearing
those present shall discuss an acceptable Plan of Corrective Action. If
possible, a Plan of Corrective Action shall be agreed upon and reduced to
writing during the hearing. Otherwise, a proposed Plan of Corrective Action
shall be presented by the owner or his agent to the Town within ten (10) days
following the Hearing. There shall not be a uniform timeframe placed on
Corrective Action Plans, but the timeframe shall be reasonable as determined by
the Code Enforcement officer on a case-by-case basis. This Article is intended
to provide a reasonable degree of flexibility in administration so that work
can be done in a quality manner. This Article was formulated to balance the
interests of the property owner with the welfare of the greater community and
adjacent property owner interests.
   (2)   This Plan of Corrective Action must include, but is not limited to, a
description of the work to be done, by whom, and a reasonably specific
schedule. Plans shall be reviewed by the Town Code Enforcement Officer and work
is to commence within thirty (30) days of staff approval. The Plan of
Corrective Action shall be attached and incorporated into an Order to Take
Corrective Action.
   (3)   In any case where the preliminary investigation reveals that a
building at issue appears to be unsafe and especially dangerous to life because
of liability to fire or because of bad conditions of walls, overloaded floors,
defective construction, decay, unsafe wiring or heating systems, inadequate
means of egress and other causes, the Code Enforcement Officer shall contact
the Haywood County Building Inspector, who shall conduct further proceedings
following the Town of Canton's Minimum Housing Standards (Part 9, Chapter 2 of
this Code) to the extent the same are consistent with the statutory procedures
set forth in G.S. § 160A-439 and the procedures of said statute in the event
the Minimum Housing Standards are inconsistent with G.S. § 160A-439.
Alternatively, the County Building Inspector may utilize the procedures set
forth for building condemnation under the State Building Code as set forth in
G.S. § 160A-426, et. seq.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1214 Service of notice of violations and orders to take corrective
action.
   (a)   Notice of Violations and Orders issued by the Code Enforcement Officer
pursuant to this Article shall be served upon all persons of interest either
personally or by registered or certified mail so long as the means used are
reasonably designed to achieve actual notice. When service is made by
registered or certified mail, a copy of the Notice of Violation or Order may
also be sent by regular mail. Service shall be deemed sufficient if the
registered or certified mail is refused, but the regular mail is not returned
by the post office within ten (10) days after the mailing. If regular mail is
used, a notice of the pending proceedings shall be posted in a conspicuous
place on the premise affected.
   (b)   If the identities of any owners or the whereabouts of persons are
unknown and cannot be ascertained by the public officer in the exercise of
reasonable diligence, or, if the owners are known but have refused to accept
service by registered or certified mail, and the public officer makes an
affidavit to that effect, then the serving of the complaint or order upon the
owners or other persons may be made by publication in a newspaper having
general circulation in the city at least once no later than the time at which
personal service would be required under the provisions of this Part. When
service is made by publication, a notice of the pending proceedings shall be
posted in a conspicuous place on the premises thereby affected.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1215 Nature of corrective actions.
   All corrective actions, as required under this Article G, shall be completed
in accordance with North Carolina Building Codes. Before any work is begun, all
necessary Building Permits must be obtained, as required.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1216 Enforcement and penalties.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any owner or parties in interest to be in
violation of any of the provisions of this Article.
   (b)   Violations are not considered criminal in nature.
   (c)   Any person who violates a provision of this Article or fails to comply
with any order made thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken, or who
shall fail to comply with such order as affirmed or modified by appeal within
the time fixed herein, shall severally, for each and every such violation and
noncompliance respectively, be issued a Civil Penalty Citation in the amount
outlined below in Subsection.
   (d)   The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the
violation, or authorize its continuance.
   (e)   Penalties for failure to comply:
   (1)   Initial registration. Failure to initially register vacant property
with the Town within the timeframe required is a violation punishable by the
issuance of a civil penalty citation in the amount of $50.00.
   (2)   Annual registration. Failure to register annually a vacant Property is
a violation punishable by the issuance of a civil penalty citation in the
amount of $50.00.
   (3)   Security requirements for vacant properties. Failure to meet security
requirements established within this Article is a violation punishable by the
issuance of a civil penalty citation in the amount of $50.00.
   (4)   Failure to submit Plan. Failure to submit Plan of Corrective Action is
a violation punishable by the issuance of a civil penalty citation in the
amount of $50.00.
   (5)   Failure to begin implementation of Plan. Failure to begin Plan of
Corrective Action within thirty (30) days of approval by staff is a violation
punishable by the immediate issuance of a civil penalty citation in the amount
of $500.00. From that date, if implementation is not begun within fourteen (14)
days, civil penalties will begin accruing at a rate of $250/day each day
thereafter until agreed upon work commences.
   (6)   Failure to complete Plan of Corrective Action and requirements
contained within. When not otherwise specified, failure to meet any stated and
agreed upon corrective actions contained within the Plan of Corrective Action
within ten (10) days of the agreed upon completion date shall constitute a
separate offense, a violation punishable by the issuance of an additional civil
penalty citation in the amount of $250 and $250 each day thereafter unless
documented extenuating circumstances are presented and deemed justifiable by
the Code Enforcement Officer.
   (f)   The Town may seek to recover accrued civil penalties together with all
costs by filing a civil action in the general court of justice in the nature of
a suit to collect a debt.
   (g)   This Article may also be enforced by any appropriate equitable action.
   (h)   Any one, all, or any combination of the foregoing penalties and
remedies may be used to enforce this Article.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1217 Appeal.
   Any person who has received a Notice of Violation/Order for Corrective
Action under this, Article G, may appeal the order to the Board of Adjustment
by giving notice of appeal in writing to the Town of Canton's Code Enforcement
Officer and to the Clerk to the Board within ten (10) days following issuance
of the Notice of Violation/Order for Corrective Action. In the absence of an
appeal to the Board of Adjustment within the prescribed time, the order of the
Code Enforcement Officer or his/her designee shall be final. The Board of
Adjustment shall hear appeals within a reasonable time after receipt of the
Notice of Appeal and it may modify, affirm or revoke the order. Any person
aggrieved by a decision or order of the Code Enforcement Officer shall have the
remedies provided in G.S. § 160A-446.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1218 Validity.
   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phase of this Article is
for any reason held to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity
of the remaining portions of this Article which here adopted both in part and
as a whole. The Town Board hereby declares that it would have passed this
Article and each section, subsection, clause and phrase thereof, irrespective
of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or
phrases be declared invalid.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1219 Conflict with other provisions.
   In the event any provision, standard or requirement of this Article is found
to be in conflict with any provision of any other ordinance or code of the Town
of Canton, the provision which establishes the higher standard or more
stringent requirement for the promotion and protection of the health and safety
of the residents of the jurisdiction shall prevail. The North Carolina State
Building Code, current edition, shall serve as the standard for all
alterations, repairs, additions, removals, demolitions and other acts of
building made or required pursuant to this Article.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1220 Amendments.
   The Town Board may from time to time amend, supplement, or change the
provisions and requirements of this Article. Any such amendment shall be by
ordinance of the Town Board.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
Section 9-1221 Preemption.
   Except as specifically preempted by G.S. §§ 160A-441, et. seq., 160A-439 or
Town Ordinances subsequently promulgated pursuant to G.S. § 160A-439, et. seq.,
this Article shall apply to all vacant and occupied commercial properties in
the C-1 Central Business, C-2 General Business, C-3 Neighborhood Business, C-
4 Highway Business, I-1 Light Industrial, and I-2 Heavy Industrial Business
Districts within the Town of Canton and its ETJ Extra Territorial Jurisdiction
to the extent applicable by law.
(Ord. of 8/27/15)
